question: If an institution that acts as a clearing member is working out its CVA own-funds requirement under Title VI using the reduced exposure at default from paragraphs 3–5, and it also uses the Section 5 method for its exposures to a client, what maturity factor can it use for that client calculation?
gold_answer: In that situation, the institution that acts as a clearing member can use a maturity factor of 0.21 when it applies the Section 5 method to calculate the own funds requirement for its exposures to a client. [#TGT:f6e5657c2d3e0f5e] This sits alongside (and does not replace) the separate permission for a clearing member to use a reduced exposure at default—specifically, the reduced exposure at default that results from the calculations in paragraphs 3, 4 and 5—when calculating its own funds requirements for CVA risk under Title VI. [#SRC:e0f6e3ca4abbfbea] So, the combined approach is: use the reduced exposure at default from paragraphs 3–5 for the Title VI CVA own-funds calculation, and, when the calculation step concerns exposures to a client under the Section 5 method, apply the 0.21 maturity factor within that Section 5 computation. [#SRC:e0f6e3ca4abbfbea] [#TGT:f6e5657c2d3e0f5e] The 0.21 maturity factor is explicitly allowed as a derogation from point (d) of Article 282(4) for that Section 5 client-exposure calculation. [#TGT:f6e5657c2d3e0f5e]
source_text: An institution that acts as a clearing member may use the reduced exposure at default resulting from the calculations set out in paragraphs 3 , 4 and 5 for the purposes of calculating its own funds requirements for CVA risk in accordance with Title VI.
target_text: By way of derogation from point (d) of Article 282(4) , where an institution that acts as a clearing member uses the method set out in Section 5 to calculate the own funds requirement for its exposures to a client , that institution may use a maturity factor of 0.21 in that calculation.

question: If a firm needs to mark eligible deposits so they can be spotted right away, can it do this by marking the depositor’s account instead of each deposit, and should the marker stay on the account even if the balance is zero or negative?
gold_answer: Yes—so long as the firm’s method makes eligible deposits immediately identifiable, marking can be implemented in a way that achieves that outcome by using an account marker for eligible depositors. [#TGT:60b306349873ce31] The PRA explains that, for meeting Depositor Protection 11.1, marking eligible deposits may be done by marking accounts of eligible depositors that contain eligible deposits, which indicates that an account-level marker can be an acceptable way to implement the marking requirement. [#SRC:91baf6dd072390d5] If an account that has the eligible deposit marker later has a nil balance, or its balance becomes negative, the PRA does not expect the firm to remove the marker. [#SRC:91baf6dd072390d5] Accordingly, the firm should design its marking process so the marker supports immediate identification of eligible deposits while remaining in place on the relevant account even through zero or negative balances. [#TGT:60b306349873ce31] [#SRC:91baf6dd072390d5]
source_text: For the purposes of meeting Depositor Protection 11.1 , the PRA considers the marking of eligible deposits may be achieved by marking accounts of eligible depositors which contain eligible deposits. For the avoidance of doubt, where such an account has a nil balance, or the balance becomes negative, the PRA does not expect firms to remove the eligible deposit marker.
target_text: A firm must mark eligible deposits in a way that allows for the immediate identification of such deposits .

question: How should a firm reconcile the requirement to complete the investigation referred to in 2.1 for the first financial year ending on or after 1 January 2017 with the separate requirement that an investigation into the firm’s financial condition (in respect of its insurance business) be made every third financial year by the appropriate actuary?
gold_answer: A firm must treat the first financial year ending on or after 1 January 2017 as a mandatory completion point for the investigation referred to in 2.1, and it must also ensure that investigations into its financial condition for its insurance business occur on a recurring every-third-financial-year cycle and are carried out by the appropriate actuary. [#SRC:fbe9526d072301c2] [#TGT:3caa12ffd3bf3daf] In practice, this means the firm cannot defer the 2.1 investigation beyond that first qualifying year-end, even if its “every third financial year” cadence would otherwise place the next investigation later. [#SRC:fbe9526d072301c2] [#TGT:3caa12ffd3bf3daf] The firm should therefore (i) identify the first financial year that ends on or after 1 January 2017 and ensure the 2.1 investigation is completed for that year, and (ii) separately track the ongoing third-financial-year schedule for investigations into the firm’s financial condition in respect of its insurance business, ensuring each such investigation is made by the appropriate actuary. [#SRC:fbe9526d072301c2] [#TGT:3caa12ffd3bf3daf] Where the first qualifying year-end also happens to fall on a third-financial-year point, the firm can satisfy both requirements in that same year provided the investigation made by the appropriate actuary covers the firm’s financial condition in respect of its insurance business and is completed for that financial year. [#SRC:fbe9526d072301c2] [#TGT:3caa12ffd3bf3daf]
source_text: A firm must ensure that the investigation referred to in 2.1 is completed in respect of the first financial year ending on or after 1 January 2017.
target_text: A firm must ensure that an investigation is made by the appropriate actuary into the financial condition of the firm in respect of its insurance business every third financial year .

question: When assessing how liquidity stresses at counterparties and other market participants could adversely affect an insurer, how should the insurer treat “sleeper collateral,” and what specific counterparty action involving sleeper collateral is identified as a potential stress transmission channel?
gold_answer: In evaluating how liquidity stresses at counterparties and other market participants could harm the insurer, the insurer should treat “sleeper collateral” as an unposted but contractually committed collateral amount that may become payable if and when the counterparty calls it. [#TGT:17e755beec91fb74] This matters because the passage identifies “recalling sleeper collateral” as a concrete counterparty action that can occur under stress and that could adversely affect the insurer’s liquidity position. [#SRC:4fbd64abc69cb404] The combined implication is that the insurer’s assessment should not view sleeper collateral as irrelevant simply because it has not been posted; instead, it should recognize it as a contingent liquidity demand embedded in contractual obligations that can be activated by counterparty behavior. [#TGT:17e755beec91fb74] In the same stress context, the insurer should consider that counterparties may take other actions—such as selling similar assets affecting market prices, not posting collateral required, or opening valuation disputes—that can compound liquidity pressures alongside a sleeper-collateral recall. [#SRC:4fbd64abc69cb404] Overall, sleeper collateral should be incorporated as a potential call-driven outflow risk specifically linked to the identified recall action under liquidity stress. [#SRC:4fbd64abc69cb404] [#TGT:17e755beec91fb74]
source_text: actions of counterparties, and other market participants experiencing liquidity stresses that could adversely affect the insurer, for instance by selling similar assets to those that the insurer may rely on for liquidity and affecting market prices, recalling sleeper collateral, 17 not posting collateral required, or opening valuation disputes.
target_text: 17. Sleeper collateral refers to the value of collateral that an insurer is contractually obliged to post to a counterparty, but has not yet posted as it has not yet been called by the counterparty.

question: If a credit union has more than £50 million in total assets and needs to do liquidity stress testing at least once a year, what should it build into the test (like the RAS, the kinds of scenarios, and what outflows/run-off to look at), and what does the PRA expect to discuss with the credit union about the test?
gold_answer: For a credit union with more than £50 million in total assets, the PRA expects periodic liquidity stress testing at least annually so the credit union can demonstrate it is holding sufficient liquid funds by considering the impact of stressed outflows. [#TGT:73d0793fc2f7a1d0] The credit union can meet this expectation through its own analysis, but that analysis should be based on a clearly articulated RAS that sets out the duration and type of stress (or stresses) the credit union aims to survive. [#SRC:505c78059496b268] The test should not be limited to mild or narrow events; it should examine a range of severe but plausible scenarios, and it should also include combined scenarios. [#SRC:505c78059496b268] Because the annual testing is meant to evaluate stressed outflows, the credit union should design the scenarios and calculations so outflows under stress are explicitly assessed as part of the liquidity impact. [#TGT:73d0793fc2f7a1d0] The PRA expects to engage with the credit union on the method used and the assumptions made, including the credit union’s view of likely run-off for different parts of the retail book, so those assumptions should be identified and supportable within the stress-testing approach. [#SRC:505c78059496b268]
source_text: The liquidity stress testing expectation referred to in paragraph 12.1 could be met by the credit union’s own analysis, which is based on a clearly articulated RAS (see paragraph 10.1 ) defining the duration and type of stress or stresses that the credit union aims to survive. The PRA expects the stress tests to consider the impact of a range of severe, but plausible scenarios (including combined scenarios). Credit unions should expect the PRA to engage with them on the method used and assumptions made, eg their assessment of the likely run-off of different elements of the retail book.
target_text: In order to ensure a credit union is holding sufficient liquid funds under Credit Unions 9.4 , the PRA expects credit unions with more than £50 million in total assets to carry out periodic (at least annual) liquidity stress testing whereby the impact of stressed outflows is considered.

question: When a firm proposes restructuring assets through a subsidiary company set up for this purpose and wholly owned within the insurance group (ie a special purpose vehicle (SPV)), what assessment must it perform about the unrestructured asset’s ongoing appropriateness for the MA portfolio liabilities, and how does that assessment interact with the PRA’s expectation that such restructuring should be used only where no viable alternative approach (eg pairing/grouping or partial recognition of cash flows) is available?
gold_answer: A firm considering restructuring assets through a wholly owned subsidiary set up for this purpose (ie a special purpose vehicle (SPV)) should treat acceptability as conditional and should not proceed unless it can both justify the need for the restructuring and demonstrate that the underlying (unrestructured) asset remains an appropriate match for the MA portfolio liabilities over the relevant period. [#TGT:c2928336a8c67d33] Specifically, in assessing the suitability of the arrangements, the PRA expects the firm first to consider whether the unrestructured asset is likely to remain appropriate over time, in a way that aligns with the duration of the restructuring arrangement and takes account of how operating conditions might change. [#SRC:0a3517a57344a4ca] In parallel, because restructuring adds complexity and consequential risks, the PRA expects these arrangements to be used only where the firm has not been able to identify a viable alternative approach, such as pairing/grouping or partial recognition of cash flows. [#TGT:c2928336a8c67d33] The firm should also ensure the restructure is appropriately recognised within the firm and the group, including recognising any changes in the risk profile of entities affected by the asset transformation, while ensuring proposals comply with applicable MA eligibility conditions. [#TGT:c2928336a8c67d33] Taken together, the firm’s decision-making should link the time-based suitability assessment of the unrestructured asset to the rationale for using an SPV restructure only as a last resort relative to the identified alternatives. [#SRC:0a3517a57344a4ca] [#TGT:c2928336a8c67d33]

target_text: Restructuring of assets through a subsidiary company set up for this purpose and wholly owned within the insurance group, ie a special purpose vehicle (SPV), 22 may be acceptable, provided that proposals comply with applicable MA eligibility conditions. It is important, however, that the restructure is appropriately recognised within the firm and the group, including any changes in the risk profile of entities affected by the asset transformation. Given the additional complexity and consequential risks that restructuring gives rise to, the PRA’s expectation is that these arrangements will only be used in cases where firms have not been able to identify a viable alternative approach, for example pairing/grouping, or partial recognition of cash flows.

question: If a firm outsources a material function, what needs to be in the contract about inspections/audits, and what extra message does the PRA expect the firm to give the service provider about the Bank and PRA’s statutory powers (including what happens if the firm forgets to tell them)?
gold_answer: For a material outsourced function, the firm should ensure the outsourcing terms cover both contractual oversight and regulatory awareness. The contract should provide for the rights of firms and the PRA to inspect and audit the service provider in relation to the material outsourced function. [#SRC:c8d1fead98534aaa] Separately, the PRA expects the firm to tell the service provider that, beyond the chapter’s later expectations on access, audit, and information rights, the Bank and PRA also have statutory information-gathering and investigatory powers. [#TGT:a387300e34c8188b] The firm should explain that some of these statutory powers may apply directly to outsourced service providers as well as firms, and it should use the powers and requirements described in Tables 6 and 7 as the basis for that awareness (while recognising those tables are not exhaustive). [#TGT:a387300e34c8188b] The firm should also make clear that if it fails to provide this awareness, that does not affect whether the statutory powers and requirements apply in practice. [#TGT:a387300e34c8188b]
source_text: the rights of firms and the PRA to inspect and audit the service provider with regard to the material outsourced function (see Chapter 8 );
target_text: Independent of the expectations on access, audit, and information rights set out later in this chapter, the Bank and PRA have a range of statutory information-gathering and investigatory powers, some of which may apply directly to outsourced service providers as well as firms. The PRA expects firms to make service providers aware of the powers and requirements as set out in Tables 6 and 7 below, which are not exhaustive. However, failure to do so will not affect their applicability.

question: When a firm is applying the MA within the calculation of the SCR for illiquid assets, how should it treat the Chapter 4 expectations on risk identification and internal model calibration/validation, including the example expectations for Income Producing Real Estate (IPRE) loans, and what must it do if it decides those expectations are not applicable to other assets with similar features?
gold_answer: A firm applying the MA within the calculation of the SCR should treat the PRA’s Chapter 4 expectations as the relevant framework for conducting the risk identification exercise and for calibrating and validating internal models for illiquid assets. [#SRC:19764d3f3782ec08] In that context, the example expectations described for Income Producing Real Estate (IPRE) loans should be used as a reference point, and the firm should actively assess whether those example expectations are suitable for other relevant illiquid assets in its portfolio given the heterogeneity of such assets. [#TGT:4abb726bc4a4f4e9] If the firm concludes that the IPRE-related expectations are not applicable to assets that have similar features to IPRE, it must be able to provide a justification explaining why they are not applicable, and it must provide that justification upon request. [#TGT:4abb726bc4a4f4e9] The PRA’s approach to seeking assurance against these expectations is described as proportionate and is linked to using similar criteria to those discussed in paragraph 2.6 of this SS, which informs how the firm should anticipate supervisory review of its Chapter 4 work. [#TGT:4abb726bc4a4f4e9] Overall, the firm should align its MA/SCR internal model work for illiquid assets with these Chapter 4 expectations and be prepared to evidence applicability decisions and any non-applicability rationale. [#SRC:19764d3f3782ec08]
source_text: Chapter 2 of this SS clarifies the PRA’s expectations where internal credit assessments are used as part of determining the basic FS, including some expectations that are specific to restructured assets (including ERMs). Chapter 3 then sets out some principles to be applied when assessing the risks from guarantees embedded within ERMs, for the purposes of verifying the appropriateness of the FS (including any FS additions); these apply to both restructured ERM notes and un-restructured ERMs that may be included in the MA portfolio under the limited proportion of assets with highly predictable cash flows. Chapter 4 sets out the PRA’s expectations regarding the risk identification exercise and the risk calibration and validation of internal models for illiquid assets.
target_text: This chapter sets out the PRA’s expectations of firms regarding the risk identification exercise and the risk calibration and validation of internal models (particularly in respect of the application of the MA within the calculation of the SCR) for illiquid assets. It includes, as an example, several expectations, specific to Income Producing Real Estate (IPRE) loans. Given the heterogeneity of illiquid assets, the PRA expects firms to consider whether these expectations are applicable to other relevant assets within their portfolios. Where firms consider the expectations are not applicable to assets with similar features to IPRE, the PRA expects them to provide, upon request, a justification of why this is the case. The PRA will seek assurance against these expectations in a proportionate way, using similar criteria to those discussed in paragraph 2.6 of this SS.

question: If a liability is secured on property, when can it still be written down because the security is a floating charge, and how should the plan describe the order of writing it down compared with lower-ranking liabilities?
gold_answer: Even if a liability is secured on property, it can still be eligible for write-down where the security is a charge that, when created, was a floating charge, because FSMA section 377B treats other property-secured amounts as excluded liabilities but does not treat floating-charge-secured amounts the same way. [#TGT:8a41e3fa3a9296cc] The write-down plan should then connect that eligibility to the PRA’s expectation that write-down plans broadly respect the creditor hierarchy so that the overall outcome for policyholders and other creditors is better than if no order were made. [#SRC:3ab0329fffa4af96] The plan should also reflect the PRA’s concern that floating charges are often granted to inward reinsurance creditors who are contractually subordinated to rank alongside direct policyholders (who have a statutory priority), and that writing down floating-charge-secured liabilities is intended to prevent those creditors from receiving an inappropriate and unintended priority. [#SRC:3ab0329fffa4af96] As a result, where a floating-charge-secured liability is not subordinated in that way, the plan should generally state that it would be written down only after lower-ranking liabilities, in line with the creditor hierarchy. [#SRC:3ab0329fffa4af96]
source_text: The PRA anticipates that write-down plans will broadly respect the creditor hierarchy in order to ‘lead to a better outcome for the insurer’s policyholders and other creditors (taken as a whole) than not making the order.’ 7 The PRA also recognises that while liabilities secured by floating charges are not excluded liabilities, 8 and may therefore be written-down, this is intended to ‘avoid creating an inappropriate and unintended priority for inward reinsurance creditors, who are often granted a floating charge but contractually subordinated to rank alongside direct policyholders (who have a statutory priority)’. 9 Accordingly, liabilities secured by floating charges which are not subordinated in this way would generally be expected to be written down only after lower-ranking liabilities, in accordance with the creditor hierarchy.
target_text: 8. Section 377B(1)(d) of FSMA treats ‘an amount secured on property of any kind, other than an amount secured by a charge which, as created, was a floating charge’ as an excluded liability (the term ‘floating charge’ is then defined in section 377B(2) of FSMA).

question: When calculating the add-on of a hedging set under Articles 280a to 280f, what is the meaning of the hedging set supervisory factor coefficient ‘ε’, and how is εj for a specific hedging set j determined?
gold_answer: For purposes of calculating the add-on of a hedging set under Articles 280a to 280f, the term “hedging set supervisory factor coefficient” refers to the coefficient denoted by ε that is used in that add-on calculation. [#TGT:ce763c4d8b7f8eb2] Where the coefficient is indexed by hedging set, εj means the hedging set supervisory factor coefficient for hedging set j, and it is not chosen ad hoc; instead, εj must be determined in accordance with Article 280. [#SRC:b96f4cdc656c880c] In practical terms, this links the add-on calculation context (Articles 280a to 280f) to the method for fixing the coefficient value for each hedging set (Article 280): the add-on calculation uses ε as its supervisory factor coefficient, and for any particular hedging set j the applicable coefficient is εj as determined under Article 280. [#TGT:ce763c4d8b7f8eb2] [#SRC:b96f4cdc656c880c]

question: When deriving the basic FS for senior notes using an internal credit assessment and an assigned CQS, how should a firm treat qualitative and quantitative retained risks, including interactions and combinations of risks, given that the FS assumes the eligible asset is held to maturity except for sales needed for MA portfolio rebalancing to restore the overall matching position after material cash-flow changes?
gold_answer: A firm should derive the basic FS by identifying and reflecting the retained risks on the assumption the eligible asset is held until maturity, while recognising the limited circumstance where sale may be necessary as part of rebalancing the MA portfolio to restore the overall matching position after material changes in asset and/or liability cash flows. [#TGT:5ef1d5a9b4e454c2] In doing so, the firm’s internal credit assessment for the senior notes must consider both qualitative and quantitative sources of risk, and it must also assess how those risks may interact or combine, because the PRA expects all risks to which the senior notes are exposed (including combinations) to be captured through the internal credit assessment, the assigned CQS, and therefore the derivation of the basic FS. [#SRC:baebcddb0c257a4e] Retained risks explicitly include qualitative and quantitative risks, and qualitative risks can include matters such as the strength of terms and conditions in the loan agreement or a lack of default data, while quantitative risks can include economic or market stresses. [#TGT:5ef1d5a9b4e454c2] Where the firm adjusts the basic FS to reflect differences in credit quality by rating notch, those adjustments should still be grounded in the same comprehensive internal credit assessment and assigned CQS that incorporate the full set of relevant risks and their interactions. [#SRC:baebcddb0c257a4e]
source_text: As mentioned in paragraphs 2.1 and 2.3 above, firms should consider both qualitative and quantitative sources of risk in their credit risk assessments. The PRA expects that all of the risks to which the senior notes are exposed (including combinations of risks) will be considered in the internal credit assessment, the assigned CQS and therefore the derivation of the basic FS (including any adjustments made to it in order to take account of differences in credit quality by rating notch).
target_text: The overarching aim of the FS is to determine how much of the spread on an eligible asset should be taken to reflect the risks retained by the firm on the assumption that the asset is held until maturity (other than where it proves necessary to sell it, as part of rebalancing the MA portfolio, for the purpose of restoring the overall matching position where the asset and/or liability cash flows of the portfolio have materially changed). Retained risks include both qualitative and quantitative risks. Qualitative risks may include the strength of the terms and conditions in the loan agreement or a lack of default data. Quantitative risks may include economic or market stresses. Internal credit assessments must also consider how these risks may interact (as per Matching Adjustment 7.2(1) ). The examples of risks listed in this paragraph are not exhaustive.

question: When determining the basic fundamental spread (basic FS), how should a firm treat assets with credit ratings provided by credit rating agencies (CRAs) versus internally-rated assets, and how does the definition of “credit rating” and “credit rating agency” affect that distinction?
gold_answer: In determining the basic fundamental spread (basic FS), a firm is expected to group assets in an MA portfolio by credit quality step (CQS), asset class, and duration, and then apply different levels of judgement depending on whether an asset’s credit assessment is a “credit rating” from a “credit rating agency” or an internal assessment. [#SRC:85642c5db4f699c7] The terms “credit rating” and “credit rating agency” are defined in regulation 2(1) of the IRPR regulations, so the firm should use those definitions to identify which assets fall into the CRA-rated category for this purpose. [#TGT:45aa7b23d23d130a] For assets that have CRA-provided credit ratings (as identified using those IRPR definitions), the CQS assignment process for basic FS is described as relatively prescriptive, including any adjustments to reflect differences in credit quality by rating notch, with the firm’s main judgement being how it categorises the asset class. [#SRC:85642c5db4f699c7] By contrast, for internally-rated assets (i.e., assets not relying on a CRA “credit rating” as defined), the firm must exercise more judgement in determining the internal credit assessment and the CQS that should apply. [#SRC:85642c5db4f699c7] This distinction matters because the definitional boundary determines whether the firm follows the more prescriptive CRA-based assignation approach or the more judgement-based internal approach. [#TGT:45aa7b23d23d130a]
source_text: To determine the basic fundamental spread (basic FS), 2 the PRA expects that a firm will need to group the assets in an MA portfolio by credit quality step (CQS), asset class and duration. For assets with credit ratings provided by credit rating agencies 3 (CRAs) and referred to in Solvency Capital Requirement - Standard Formula 1D , the CQS and hence the assignation process for determining the basic FS, including any adjustments to reflect differences in credit quality by rating notch, is relatively prescriptive, with the only judgement being over the categorisation by asset class. In contrast, for internally-rated assets 4 , there is more judgement involved in determining the internal credit assessment and the CQS that should apply.
target_text: 3. Credit rating and credit rating agency are defined in regulation 2(1) of the IRPR regulations.

question: If a firm is told by its supervisor that it qualifies for Simplified Obligations, does it still need to use the EBA recovery-plan scenario guidelines, and what minimum set of scenarios should it include?
gold_answer: Yes. Being notified by its supervisor that it meets the eligibility criteria means the firm is in scope of the PRA’s Simplified Obligations, under which reduced recovery planning obligations apply for scenarios and the information template. [#SRC:1714a0d1f587bfcb] However, the PRA still expects firms to follow the EBA ‘Guidelines on the range of scenarios to be used in recovery plans’ together with the expectations in the SS, so eligibility for Simplified Obligations does not eliminate the need to align scenario selection with those guidelines. [#TGT:9394388668fe0fa9] At a minimum, an eligible firm should include at least two scenarios drawn from the EBA guidelines that are severe enough to test the recovery plan and that best match the firm’s business model. [#TGT:9394388668fe0fa9] In addition, consistent with the EBA guidelines and the PRA’s stated expectation for all firms (including those eligible for Simplified Obligations), the firm should include a scenario that combines system-wide and idiosyncratic events. [#TGT:9394388668fe0fa9] The combined-event scenario is specifically expected because it is described as the most challenging type, requiring the firm to consider trade-offs between capital and liquidity impacts from recovery options when developing its recovery strategy. [#TGT:9394388668fe0fa9]
source_text: The PRA applies Simplified Obligations for recovery planning (Simplified Obligations) to firms that have been notified by their supervisor that they meet the eligibility criteria. For these firms, the reduced recovery planning obligations apply in respect of scenarios and the information template (paragraphs 2.54 – 2.55 and 2.70 ). Additional information in relation to the approach that smaller and less complex firms should take in respect of certain aspects of recovery planning is included where relevant in this SS.
target_text: The EBA has published ‘Guidelines on the range of scenarios to be used in recovery plans’. The PRA expects firms to follow these guidelines alongside the expectations set out in this SS. Firms that are eligible for Simplified Obligations should include at least two of the scenarios set out in the EBA guidelines that are sufficiently severe to test the recovery plan and are most relevant to the firm’s business model. In accordance with the EBA guidelines, firms should include a scenario with a combination of system-wide and idiosyncratic events. The PRA therefore expects firms, including those eligible for Simplified Obligations, to include a combined system-wide and idiosyncratic event, as these scenarios are the most challenging, as firms need to consider potential trade-offs between capital and liquidity impacts from recovery options when developing a recovery strategy.

question: For a CRR firm preparing its self-assessment of its ability to deliver important business services within impact tolerances, how must it incorporate (i) additional risks arising from elsewhere in its group and (ii) the CRR consolidation entity’s work on important group business services, including the disruption scenario and the scope of entities to be assessed?
gold_answer: A CRR firm’s self-assessment must go beyond its own operations by identifying extra risks to staying within impact tolerances that come from elsewhere in its group, and it must also be informed by the CRR consolidation entity’s work on important group business services. [#SRC:525172756112897c] In practice, the CRR consolidation entity’s work that informs the self-assessment includes an assessment of whether each member of the CRR consolidation entity’s consolidation group that provides an important group business service could remain within the impact tolerance set for that service when facing a severe but plausible disruption to its operations. [#TGT:4e1aaf4d13ad6adb] The linkage is that the self-assessment’s group-risk identification is complemented by (and should take account of) the consolidation-group-wide testing of resilience against a defined disruption scenario for each important group business service. [#SRC:525172756112897c] [#TGT:4e1aaf4d13ad6adb] Accordingly, the CRR firm should ensure its self-assessment reflects both (i) group-derived risks affecting its ability to deliver important business services within impact tolerances and (ii) the consolidation entity’s conclusions about whether each relevant consolidation group member can remain within the applicable impact tolerance under severe-but-plausible disruption conditions. [#SRC:525172756112897c] [#TGT:4e1aaf4d13ad6adb]
source_text: identify any additional risks to their ability to deliver important business services within impact tolerances arising from elsewhere in their group. In the case of a CRR firm, the self-assessment should also be informed by any work the CRR consolidation entity has undertaken to comply with the requirements under Rules 8.6 , 8.7 and 8.8 , regarding important group business services and whether each member of the CRR consolidation entity’s consolidation group could remain within impact tolerance.
target_text: A CRR consolidation entity must assess whether each member of the CRR consolidation entity’s consolidation group providing each important group business service could remain within the impact tolerance set for that important group business service in the event of a severe but plausible disruption to its operations.

question: If you are a managing agent, what does “SCR” mean in the rules that are applied to you (3.1(2)(b), 3.8(2)(c), and 6.1(1)(i)), and what do you have to calculate for each syndicate you manage because of that?
gold_answer: For a managing agent, in the context of 3.1(2)(b), 3.8(2)(c) and 6.1(1)(i) as they apply to managing agents, “SCR” is not read in a generic way; it is interpreted as the notional syndicate SCR that managing agents must calculate under Solvency Capital Requirement - General Provisions 8.2. [#SRC:44175f318dae3378] That interpretation matters because it ties the meaning of “SCR” in those applied provisions directly to a specific calculated figure (the notional syndicate SCR), rather than any other SCR measure. [#SRC:44175f318dae3378] As a result, you must calculate a notional SCR for each syndicate which you manage, so that each syndicate has its own notional SCR available to be used wherever those applied provisions refer to “SCR.” [#TGT:aabb18c60cd5c8ad] Put simply, the calculation is required at the level of each individual syndicate you manage, and that per-syndicate notional SCR is what the applied provisions mean when they say “SCR.” [#TGT:aabb18c60cd5c8ad] [#SRC:44175f318dae3378]
source_text: (1) 3.1 (2)(b), 3.8 (2)(c) and 6.1 (1)(i), as applied to managing agents , the reference to “ SCR ” is to be interpreted as a reference to the notional syndicate SCR calculated by managing agents as required by Solvency Capital Requirement - General Provisions 8.2 .
target_text: A managing agent must calculate a notional SCR for each syndicate which it manages.

question: If a firm is in a group covered by 2.1(3), what does it need to have in place at group level to check whether important group business services can stay within impact tolerance during a severe but plausible disruption, and when would 22.2, 22.3 and 22.4 not apply because of where the parent undertaking’s head office is?
gold_answer: For a firm in a group covered by 2.1(3), the firm must make sure the group’s strategies, processes and systems let the firm assess whether important group business services could remain within the impact tolerance if there is a severe but plausible disruption to the firm’s operations. [#SRC:43a647fe4cce5cd9] In the same 2.1(3) setting, the firm also needs to identify whether a specific disapplication condition is met: 22.2, 22.3 and 22.4 do not apply if the group’s parent undertaking has its head office in a third country that is an overseas jurisdiction designated under regulation 11 in relation to regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations for insurance group supervision, and paragraph (3) of regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations applies. [#TGT:b6b6500b2b9939c8] This means the firm’s operational resilience assessment capability at group level (focused on impact tolerance for important group business services under severe but plausible disruption) is a required capability for the firm as a group member, while the applicability of 22.2–22.4 depends on the parent undertaking’s head-office jurisdiction and the stated IRPR regulation conditions. [#SRC:43a647fe4cce5cd9] [#TGT:b6b6500b2b9939c8]
source_text: Where a firm is a member of a group covered by 2.1(1) , 2.1(2) or, subject to 22.5 , 2.1(3) the firm must ensure that the strategies, processes and systems at the level of the group of which it is a member enable the firm to assess whether important group business services at the level of the group could remain within the impact tolerance in the event of a severe but plausible disruption to its operations.
target_text: Where a firm is a member of a group covered by 2.1(3) , 22.2 , 22.3 and 22.4 do not apply if, the third country in which the group's parent undertaking has its head office is an overseas jurisdiction designated under regulation 11 in relation to regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations in respect of insurance group supervision and paragraph (3) of regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations applies.

question: If a firm wants to use a matching adjustment when working out the best estimate of its insurance or reinsurance obligations, what permission does it need first, and what key confirmations/evidence should be in its initial MA application so the PRA can be satisfied?
gold_answer: Before a firm uses a matching adjustment in the calculation of the best estimate of its insurance or reinsurance obligations (by applying it to the relevant risk-free interest rate term structure), it must have a matching adjustment permission. [#TGT:78efaa111a0c4a1d] The way to get to that point is through an MA application under the IRPR regulations, where the PRA must be satisfied that the firm meets the MA eligibility conditions in regulation 4 of the IRPR regulations and Chapter 2 of the Matching Adjustment Part. [#SRC:706be7f8963a27d5] In its initial MA application, the firm must include written confirmation that it complies with the MA eligibility conditions. [#SRC:706be7f8963a27d5] The text also indicates that, for regulation 4(4) of the IRPR regulations and Matching Adjustment 2.2(6), firms are expected to provide this written confirmation. [#SRC:706be7f8963a27d5] For the other MA eligibility conditions, the firm is expected to add documentary evidence that backs up its written confirmation. [#SRC:706be7f8963a27d5] Taken together, the firm should view the permission as a prerequisite: it cannot apply the matching adjustment in the best estimate calculation unless and until that permission is in place. [#TGT:78efaa111a0c4a1d]
source_text: In order for a firm to apply an MA under the IRPR regulations, the PRA must be satisfied that the firm meets the MA eligibility conditions as set out in regulation 4 of the IRPR regulations and Chapter 2 of the Matching Adjustment Part . As required by Matching Adjustment 3.1 , a firm's initial MA application must contain written confirmation of its compliance with the MA eligibility conditions. For regulation 4(4) of the IRPR regulations and Matching Adjustment 2.2(6) , firms are expected to provide this written confirmation. For other MA eligibility conditions, firms are expected to provide documentary evidence to support their written confirmation, including:
target_text: A firm must not apply a matching adjustment to the relevant risk-free interest rate term structure to calculate the best estimate of its insurance or reinsurance obligations unless it has a matching adjustment permission .

question: If a firm has a record that was made under SYSC 2.2.1R of the PRA Handbook and existed on 31 December 2015, how long does it need to keep each version, when does the clock start, and what does it need to do if the PRA asks for it?
gold_answer: If the firm has a record that was created in line with SYSC 2.2.1R of the PRA Handbook and is within the scope described as at 31 December 2015, the firm must follow the 5.8 requirement for that record. [#SRC:6663c8b6cce3b3fe] Under that approach, each version of the record must be kept for ten years, and the ten-year period starts on the date that version is replaced by a newer, more up-to-date record. [#TGT:1d83951b815d3de2] The same rule is stated to apply to each version of the management responsibilities map, so the firm should keep version histories for both items using the supersession date as the retention trigger. [#TGT:1d83951b815d3de2] In addition to keeping the versions for the full period, the firm must be able to provide the retained versions to the PRA if the PRA requests them. [#TGT:1d83951b815d3de2] This ties the specific “record created … as at 31 December 2015” population to a concrete retention-and-production outcome: ten-year retention per version, measured from supersession, plus readiness to deliver to the PRA on request. [#SRC:6663c8b6cce3b3fe] [#TGT:1d83951b815d3de2]
source_text: A firm must comply with 5.8 in relation to any record created in accordance with SYSC 2.2.1R of the PRA Handbook as at 31 December 2015.
target_text: Each version of both the management responsibilities map and the record in 5.4 must be retained for a period of ten years from the date on which it was superseded by a more up-to-date record, and must be provided to the PRA on request.

question: For a firm with a TMTP permission that decides to apply less than the maximum transitional deduction, what must it disclose and how should it determine the “maximum amount,” including how that maximum is derived under the TMTP method or a legacy approach in its permission?
gold_answer: Where a firm with a TMTP permission chooses to apply less than the maximum transitional deduction, it should treat the “maximum amount” as the upper bound of the permitted range (with the applied amount falling between zero and that maximum) and then disclose both figures. [#SRC:e6ce08835f92cf1c] The “maximum amount” for this purpose is the maximum number produced either by the TMTP method in Transitional Measures on Technical Provisions 5 or by the legacy approach described in the firm’s relevant permission, so the firm must identify which of those two bases applies to it when determining the maximum. [#TGT:f321e44c98b40d33] In terms of transparency and supervisory engagement, when applying less than the maximum, the PRA expects the firm to include both the maximum amount and the actual TMTP amount in the notes to market disclosures and to share the same information with its supervision team. [#SRC:e6ce08835f92cf1c] The firm should also maintain a transparent, consistently applied approach to determining the TMTP benefit it applies, and the PRA expects that approach to be followed across all Solvency II reporting (including QRTs) and reflected in the firm’s ORSA and risk management framework. [#SRC:e6ce08835f92cf1c]
source_text: For all firms with a TMTP permission there is a requirement that the amount of the transitional deduction to be applied by a firm is to be between zero and a maximum amount. 6 If a decision is taken by such a firm to apply less than the maximum amount, the PRA expects the firm to include both the maximum amount and actual TMTP amount in the notes to market disclosures, and to share this information with its supervision team. The firm should maintain a transparent approach to determining the amount of TMTP benefit it is applying. The PRA expects this approach to be followed consistently by firms within all Solvency II reporting including for Quarterly Reporting Templates (QRTs). This approach should also be reflected within a firm’s ORSA and risk management framework.
target_text: 6. The amount is the maximum number derived from the TMTP method in Transitional Measures on Technical Provisions 5 or the legacy approach outlined in the relevant firm’s permission.

question: If a firm is working out the basic FS for senior notes, what risks does it need to look at in its internal credit assessment, and how does that connect to the FS idea that the asset is held to maturity (except when selling is needed to rebalance the MA portfolio after big cash-flow changes)?
gold_answer: To work out the basic FS for senior notes, the firm should treat the FS as a measure of how much of the spread on an eligible asset reflects the risks the firm keeps, using an assumption that the asset is held until maturity, except where selling is needed for MA portfolio rebalancing to restore the overall matching position after material changes in asset and/or liability cash flows. [#TGT:5ef1d5a9b4e454c2] Within that framework, the internal credit assessment must cover both qualitative and quantitative sources of risk, and it must also consider how those risks can interact or combine, because retained risks include both types and the interaction point is explicitly called out. [#TGT:5ef1d5a9b4e454c2] The PRA expects that all risks to which the senior notes are exposed—including combinations of risks—feed through the internal credit assessment into the assigned CQS and therefore into the derivation of the basic FS. [#SRC:baebcddb0c257a4e] Examples of qualitative risks include the strength of the terms and conditions in the loan agreement or a lack of default data, and examples of quantitative risks include economic or market stresses; these examples are not exhaustive. [#TGT:5ef1d5a9b4e454c2] Any adjustments to the basic FS to reflect differences in credit quality by rating notch should still be based on that same comprehensive assessment and CQS linkage. [#SRC:baebcddb0c257a4e]
source_text: As mentioned in paragraphs 2.1 and 2.3 above, firms should consider both qualitative and quantitative sources of risk in their credit risk assessments. The PRA expects that all of the risks to which the senior notes are exposed (including combinations of risks) will be considered in the internal credit assessment, the assigned CQS and therefore the derivation of the basic FS (including any adjustments made to it in order to take account of differences in credit quality by rating notch).
target_text: The overarching aim of the FS is to determine how much of the spread on an eligible asset should be taken to reflect the risks retained by the firm on the assumption that the asset is held until maturity (other than where it proves necessary to sell it, as part of rebalancing the MA portfolio, for the purpose of restoring the overall matching position where the asset and/or liability cash flows of the portfolio have materially changed). Retained risks include both qualitative and quantitative risks. Qualitative risks may include the strength of the terms and conditions in the loan agreement or a lack of default data. Quantitative risks may include economic or market stresses. Internal credit assessments must also consider how these risks may interact (as per Matching Adjustment 7.2(1) ). The examples of risks listed in this paragraph are not exhaustive.

question: If the FSCS thinks a depositor’s application and evidence don’t clearly connect the temporary high balance event to the deposit being over the coverage level, what does the FSCS have to do next, and what key compensation amount (and exception) should be mentioned?
gold_answer: If the FSCS concludes that the depositor’s written application and evidence do not show a strong enough link between the event that caused a temporary high balance and the eligible deposit being above the coverage level, the FSCS must promptly write to the depositor. [#SRC:9890c9f53879f676] In that written message, the compensation context should be set using the rule that the maximum compensation sum payable for the depositor’s aggregate eligible deposits is £120,000. [#TGT:336f75f8cdcde56e] At the same time, the FSCS should reflect that this maximum is subject to an exception: additional compensation may be payable where the situation falls within the cases covered by 4.3 or 4.4. [#TGT:336f75f8cdcde56e] Putting these together, the FSCS’s prompt letter should communicate both the FSCS’s view that the evidence does not sufficiently connect the temporary high balance event to the deposit exceeding the coverage level and the depositor’s compensation position under the £120,000 cap, including the possibility of additional compensation in the specified cases. [#SRC:9890c9f53879f676] [#TGT:336f75f8cdcde56e]
source_text: If the FSCS considers that the written application and evidence provided by a depositor under 10.3 does not demonstrate a sufficient link between an event giving rise to a temporary high balance and the eligible deposit being in excess of the coverage levels provided for in 4.2 , the FSCS must write promptly to that depositor to:
target_text: The maximum compensation sum payable for the aggregate eligible deposits of each depositor is £120,000, save that additional compensation may be payable in cases to which 4.3 or 4.4 apply.

question: For a firm that both covers a death risk and bears an investment risk, how should it combine the required margin of solvency adjustment with the applicable calculation steps, including any stated exclusions and the scope of when each calculation applies?
gold_answer: A firm that covers a death risk and also bears an investment risk must apply two distinct calculation directions, each triggered by a different risk condition, and then incorporate the death-risk result into the required margin of solvency. Specifically, when the firm covers a death risk, it must compute a sum using the calculation in 2.3, but it must leave out elements 2.3(4) and 2.3(5) for this purpose, and then add that computed sum to the required margin of solvency determined under any of 3.2 and 3.3 (including where that required margin is zero). [#SRC:d279a616f589ab73] Separately, the firm must apply the calculation in 2.2 only to the extent that, and only when, it bears an investment risk (i.e., the obligation is conditional and limited to the portion of business where investment risk is borne). [#TGT:8218e6bc18fdaefe] In practice, this means the firm performs the 2.2 calculation for the investment-risk-bearing part, while also performing the modified 2.3 calculation for death risk and adding that 2.3-derived sum onto the required margin of solvency produced under 3.2/3.3. [#SRC:d279a616f589ab73] [#TGT:8218e6bc18fdaefe]
source_text: Where a firm covers a death risk, a sum arrived at by applying the calculation in 2.3 (but excluding for these purposes 2.3 (4) and (5)) must be added to the required margin of solvency , including a required margin of solvency of zero, arrived at under any of 3.2 and 3.3 .
target_text: If and in so far as a firm bears an investment risk, the calculation in 2.2 must be applied.

question: How should a firm structure its booking governance so that (i) it has a clear booking taxonomy covering remote booking, split desks/shared desks, and branch bookings, and (ii) each individual booking can be traced to a responsible individual while maintaining segregation between trade entry and independent checking?
gold_answer: A firm should implement booking governance that combines a documented booking taxonomy with clear accountability for who may book and who is responsible for the correctness of each booking. The firm should first identify and classify the booking types it uses and maintain a clear, comprehensive taxonomy that defines key terms such as remote booking (in both legal-entity and geographic senses), split desks, shared desks, and the classification of branch bookings. [#TGT:670172cefe48eb87] In parallel, the firm should define and record who is permitted to book and what constitutes a booking, including whether the trader is solely responsible, and it should articulate any distinctions between traders, sales, and sales traders. [#SRC:03d5f6afa7925703] The governance should also cover individuals booking into legal entities and branches, including traders based overseas booking into UK branches, and align those scenarios to the taxonomy’s treatment of remote and branch bookings. [#SRC:03d5f6afa7925703] The PRA expects the correctness of any given booking to be traceable to at least one (and preferably only one) responsible individual, usually the trader, which should be reflected in the firm’s booking definitions and controls. [#SRC:03d5f6afa7925703] Finally, the firm should ensure trade entry is distinct from independent checking and is performed in line with segregation of duties controls, so that the taxonomy and responsibility model do not blur execution/entry with verification. [#SRC:03d5f6afa7925703]
source_text: Booking responsibilities: A firm should define and record who is permitted to book and what constitutes a booking including whether the trader is solely responsible. This should articulate the distinction, if any, between traders, sales and sales traders. This should also cover those individuals booking into legal entities and branches including traders based overseas booking into UK branches. The PRA expects the correctness of any given booking to be traced to at least one, and preferably only one, responsible individual, which will usually be the trader. Trade entry is different from the independent checking of the trade and should be performed in line with the firm’s segregation of duties controls. 37
target_text: Booking taxonomy: A firm should identify and classify the types of booking they employ and develop a clear and comprehensive taxonomy to assist with this. This should clearly define the use of terms such as remote booking (legal entity and geographic sense), split desks, and shared desks. The classification of branch bookings should also be covered. The PRA recognises that firms have already developed their own independent taxonomies to describe booking practices and is not seeking to impose common definitions for booking taxonomies at the current time. However, a set of illustrative examples have been provided in the Annex that the PRA considers to be an approximation of current industry practice and represent how the PRA has used certain terms throughout this statement.

question: Where the PRA cannot obtain adequate assurance that a home resolution authority’s regime will achieve outcomes aligned with the PRA’s and the Bank’s objectives, how does that affect the PRA’s willingness to host a branch from that jurisdiction, and how does the Bank’s ability to resolve branches on a standalone basis in certain circumstances fit into the resulting supervisory or structural expectations for an existing branch?
gold_answer: If the PRA cannot obtain adequate assurance that the home resolution authority’s resolution regime will deliver outcomes consistent with the PRA’s and the Bank’s objectives as UK resolution authority, the PRA’s stated position is that it is likely not prepared to host a branch from that jurisdiction. [#SRC:aed1e5a5beeec125] For an international bank already operating through an existing branch, the PRA indicates that the firm may be required to establish a UK subsidiary where such assurance is lacking. [#SRC:aed1e5a5beeec125] In that same insufficient-assurance scenario, the PRA further signals that supervision may need to move toward a more standalone basis, aligned with an MPE approach to resolution. [#SRC:aed1e5a5beeec125] This supervisory emphasis on standalone outcomes links to the Bank’s stated capability: the Bank has certain resolution powers over branches, including the ability to resolve branches on a standalone basis in certain circumstances. [#TGT:5b8d0f16006f4c55] Taken together, the PRA’s reluctance to host (or its push toward subsidiarisation and standalone supervision for an existing branch) is framed around ensuring resolvability aligned with UK objectives, while the Bank’s branch resolution powers provide a mechanism that can operate on a standalone basis where circumstances warrant. [#SRC:aed1e5a5beeec125] [#TGT:5b8d0f16006f4c55]
source_text: The PRA’s preferred approach is to gain assurance that the home resolution authority’s resolution regime will deliver the appropriate outcomes for the PRA’s and the Bank’s objectives as UK resolution authority. In the absence of adequate levels of assurance, the PRA will likely not be prepared to host such a branch from that jurisdiction. 53 In the case of an international bank operating through an existing branch, it may be required to establish a UK subsidiary. If there is insufficient assurance over the home state resolution arrangements, this may in turn mean that it would be necessary for the firm to be supervised on a more standalone basis consistent with a MPE approach to resolution.
target_text: 53. The Bank has certain resolution powers over branches, including the power to resolve branches on a standalone basis in certain circumstances.

question: When calculating surplus funds, how should a firm treat amounts previously added to with-profits policy liabilities that it expects to be permanent, and how does that treatment interact with the requirement to calculate with-profits policy liabilities on a retrospective aggregate basis (including the sign convention for items that increase or reduce future liability to policyholders)?
gold_answer: In calculating surplus funds, the firm should treat “permanent enhancements” as those amounts previously added to with-profits policy liabilities that the firm expects, at the time it performs the surplus funds calculation, to remain in place in all but the most extreme adverse circumstances. [#SRC:5c6323cce75978ab] This assessment is not static: if what the firm considers to be permanent additions changes over time, the firm must carry that change through into later surplus funds calculations. [#SRC:5c6323cce75978ab] In parallel, unless the circumstances in 3.2 apply, the firm must calculate the value of its with-profits policy liabilities (excluding future policy-related liabilities) by aggregating, for each with-profits policy, the retrospective value of the specified components. [#TGT:2f00d7e807d9bf79] When performing that retrospective aggregation, the firm must apply the stated sign convention: treat items that increase the future liability to policyholders as positive and items that reduce that future liability as negative. [#TGT:2f00d7e807d9bf79] Practically, this means the firm’s view of which prior additions are “permanent enhancements” informs what it expects to remain embedded in the with-profits policy liabilities at the surplus funds calculation date, while the liabilities themselves are computed using the retrospective, per-policy aggregation method and sign treatment described. [#SRC:5c6323cce75978ab] [#TGT:2f00d7e807d9bf79]

Any change in the additions that are considered permanent over time should be reflected in subsequent calculations of surplus funds.

question: If a society sends a Transfer Summary instead of the full Transfer Statement, who must get it and when must it be sent, and what does the text say the PRA is doing during the transfer process?
gold_answer: When a society uses a Transfer Summary as a replacement for the Transfer Statement, the summary is the document the society may send to its members instead of sending the full Transfer Statement. [#SRC:bc1b187c93910ab0] The summary must go to every member who is entitled to receive the notice of the meeting, and it must be sent in or with that meeting notice for the meeting where the Transfer Resolutions will be considered. [#TGT:a14772d46835cf4f] Separately from how the society communicates with members, the PRA is described as having a role in approving the Transfer Statement that must be sent to the members and in the confirmation procedure. [#SRC:bc1b187c93910ab0] The PRA is also described as continuing its ongoing prudential supervision during the transfer process, so its involvement runs through the transfer process rather than being limited to a single point in time. [#SRC:bc1b187c93910ab0] Putting these points together, the society’s choice to send a summary affects what is included with the meeting notice and who receives it, while the PRA’s described responsibilities still focus on approval of the Transfer Statement and participation in confirmation, alongside ongoing supervision during the transfer process. [#TGT:a14772d46835cf4f] [#SRC:bc1b187c93910ab0]
source_text: The chapter also describes the role of the PRA in approving the Transfer Statement which must be sent to the members and in the confirmation procedure, together with its ongoing prudential supervision during the transfer process. The Transfer Summary, 44 which a society may send to its members instead of the Transfer Statement, is also discussed.
target_text: 44. The summary of the Transfer Statement which may, in accordance with Schedule 17 to the 1986 Act, be sent, instead of the Transfer Statement, in or with the notice of the meeting at which the Transfer Resolutions are to be considered, to every member entitled to receive that notice.

question: If an international bank or UK trading bank wants to change its booking arrangements in a big way and that change could affect risk management, what does the PRA expect the firm to do, and how does this relate to being ready for an orderly resolution with minimal disruption to critical services?
gold_answer: For international banks and UK trading banks, the PRA expects the firm to inform the PRA when it plans material changes to its booking arrangements that could impact how its risk management operates. [#SRC:9efcdb7da1784680] This sits within the PRA’s wider expectations that booking arrangements should be organised to meet the threshold condition on prudent conduct of business and to support the General Organisational Requirements connected to risk management and resolvability. [#SRC:9efcdb7da1784680] The connection to Fundamental Rule 8 is that the firm must prepare for resolution so that, if needed, it can be resolved in an orderly manner with minimum disruption of critical services. [#TGT:ba7a108ec58f63f0] Because booking arrangements can affect both risk management and resolvability, the firm should view the planned-change notification as part of maintaining readiness to achieve the orderly-resolution outcome required by Fundamental Rule 8. [#SRC:9efcdb7da1784680] [#TGT:ba7a108ec58f63f0]
source_text: The PRA has a number of expectations concerning how international banks and UK trading banks should organise their booking arrangements in order to meet the threshold condition on the prudent conduct of business, their obligations under Fundamental Rules 3 , 5 , 6 and 8 , and under the General Organisational Requirements (GOR) relating to risk management and resolvability. The PRA also has an expectation under Fundamental Rule 7 and General Notification Requirement 2.3(1) that a firm should inform the PRA when it plans to make material changes to its booking arrangements that could impact how its risk management operates.
target_text: Fundamental Rule 8: A firm must prepare for resolution so, if the need arises, it can be resolved in an orderly manner with a minimum disruption of critical services.

question: For purposes of applying the MRM expectations in the supervisory statement, which UK-incorporated regulated firms are in scope because they have internal model approval, and how does that scope align with the specific types of internally developed models used to calculate regulatory capital requirements?
gold_answer: Firms in scope for the MRM expectations are regulated United Kingdom (UK)-incorporated banks, building societies, and PRA-designated investment firms that have internal model approval to calculate regulatory capital requirements. [#SRC:2eaafa63a784aad5] The relevant internal model approval is described as approval to use internally developed models for calculating regulatory capital requirements for credit risk under Internal Ratings Based approaches, for market risk under the Internal Model Approach, or for counterparty credit risk under the Internal Model Method. [#TGT:73ca40c7f7a5494b] In practical terms, a firm should treat itself as within scope when it meets both elements: (i) it is one of the UK-incorporated regulated firm types identified (bank, building society, or PRA-designated investment firm), and (ii) its internal model approval relates to one or more of the specified internally developed model categories used for regulatory capital calculations (credit risk IRB, market risk IMA, or counterparty credit risk IMM). [#SRC:2eaafa63a784aad5] [#TGT:73ca40c7f7a5494b] Conversely, the supervisory statement’s expectations are stated not to apply to firms without permission to use internal models to calculate regulatory capital, and also not to third-country firms operating in the UK through a branch; this exclusion would apply even if such firms use models, because the scope hinges on the UK-incorporated regulated firm set and the relevant permission/approval. [#SRC:2eaafa63a784aad5]
source_text: This SS is relevant to all regulated United Kingdom (UK)-incorporated banks, building societies and PRA-designated investment firms with internal model approval to calculate regulatory capital requirements. 2 The expectations in this SS do not apply to firms which do not have permission to use internal models to calculate regulatory capital and third-country firms operating in the UK through a branch. However, the PRA considers that those firms may find the proposed principles useful, and are welcome to consider them to manage model risk within their firm. Credit unions, insurers, and reinsurers are not in scope of the MRM expectations in this supervisory statement.
target_text: 2. These are firms with approval to use internally developed models to calculate regulatory capital requirements for credit risk (Internal Ratings Based approaches), market risk (Internal Model Approach) or counterparty credit risk (Internal Model Method).

question: If a firm gets a Part 4A permission to accept deposits, how quickly does it have to send the FSCS the single customer views and exclusions views, and after the FSCS receives the information required by 12.2 or 12.5 what must the FSCS tell the PRA and by when (including how this links to paying compensation within the 9.2 time limits)?
gold_answer: After a firm receives a Part 4A permission to accept deposits, it must provide the FSCS with single customer views and exclusions views within three months of receiving that permission. [#TGT:01013ac4ba4ac357] After the FSCS receives the information required by 12.2 or 12.5, the FSCS then has a separate deadline: it must, within six months of receiving that required information, advise the PRA about whether the information coming from the firm’s SCV system can be submitted to the FSCS and whether it will work with (i.e., be compatible with) the FSCS’s systems. [#SRC:615a56bb461bcd74] This FSCS advice is not just a general data-quality check; it is specifically framed around whether the FSCS’s systems can use the SCV information so that the FSCS can pay compensation within the time limits referred to in 9.2. [#SRC:615a56bb461bcd74] Put together, the firm’s obligation is a three-month delivery requirement triggered by the permission event, while the FSCS’s obligation is a six-month assessment-and-notification requirement triggered by receipt of the information required by 12.2 or 12.5 and directed to the PRA. [#TGT:01013ac4ba4ac357] [#SRC:615a56bb461bcd74]
source_text: The FSCS must, within six months of receiving the information required by 12.2 or 12.5 , advise the PRA whether the information provided by a firm’s SCV system is capable of being submitted to the FSCS and whether it is compatible with the FSCS’s systems to enable it to pay compensation within the time limits contained in 9.2 .

question: If the rules don’t say how to value a certain type of asset, what value should be used, and how should that value be changed if the firm is treated as having bought or sold that asset type because of an option when working out its exposure using the 19 to 23 adjustments?
gold_answer: If there is no specific valuation provision for a particular description of assets, the firm must still ascribe a value, using the amount that would reasonably be paid as consideration for an immediate assignment or transfer of those assets. [#TGT:596695fe437c2dff] That ascribed value is the basis for calculating exposure, because the firm’s exposure to assets of each description is determined by adjusting the value of the assets in accordance with 19 to 23. [#TGT:596695fe437c2dff] When the firm is deemed to have acquired or disposed of assets of a given description pursuant to an option, the value ascribed for assets of that description (under 18 to 19) must be increased or decreased by the value of the assets the firm is deemed to have acquired or disposed of. [#SRC:edaf68ec91a76124] So, even where the initial valuation is based on a reasonable immediate transfer price (because the rules are silent for that asset type), the firm must still apply the option-driven increase or decrease to the ascribed value for that asset description as part of the overall adjustment process used to determine exposure under 19 to 23. [#SRC:edaf68ec91a76124] [#TGT:596695fe437c2dff]
source_text: The value ascribed under 18 to 19 in respect of assets of each description must be increased or decreased by the value of assets of that description which the firm is deemed to have acquired or disposed of pursuant to an option .
target_text: A value must be ascribed to assets of each description which must be an amount determined in accordance with this Part or, where the assets are of a description for the valuation of which no provision is made in those rules, an amount which would reasonably be paid by way of consideration for an immediate assignment or transfer of such assets. The amount by which the firm is exposed to assets of each description must be determined by adjusting the value of the assets in accordance with 19 to 23 .

question: If you’re writing a short internal note on Pillar 2B, what should you say about where the PRA buffer sits compared with the TCR and the combined buffer, and how Section II links Pillar 2B to weak governance/risk management and group risk (including RFB group risk)?
gold_answer: Your note should combine (1) the capital-stack placement and function of the PRA buffer and (2) the Section II topics that explain how Pillar 2B is determined and used in supervision. [#SRC:1399703aeb306995] On placement and function, state that the PRA buffer (Pillar 2B) is an additional capital amount firms should maintain on top of their total capital requirement (TCR) and the combined buffer, and that it is intended to absorb losses that could arise in a severe stress scenario without duplicating what the combined buffers are meant to cover. [#TGT:37bcd95fb7b21224] Also state that the PRA buffer, the combined buffer, and the TCR together form the PRA’s capital framework (shown as a capital stack). [#TGT:37bcd95fb7b21224] Then link this to Section II by noting that Section II explains the purpose of the PRA buffer, how it is determined, and how it relates to the CRD buffers, and it provides the PRA’s approach to dealing with weak governance and risk management under Pillar 2B as well as group risk, including RFB group risk. [#SRC:1399703aeb306995]
source_text: Section II: Pillar 2B provides information on the purpose of the PRA buffer, how it is determined and how it relates to the CRD buffers. target_text: The PRA buffer (also referred to as Pillar 2B) is an amount of capital firms should maintain in addition to their total capital requirement 32 (TCR) and the combined buffer. The PRA buffer absorbs losses that may arise under a severe stress scenario, while avoiding duplication with the combined buffers. Together the PRA buffer, the combined buffer 33 and the TCR make up the PRA’s capital framework as illustrated by the capital stack in Figure 2.

question: When a supervisory decision results in a Decision Notice or a Final Notice, how should the PRA approach publication, and what specific type of information must it publish about the matters covered by those notices?
gold_answer: Where a supervisory decision leads to a Decision Notice or a Final Notice, the PRA’s ordinary approach is to make the action public, while still assessing the facts of the individual case and applying the stated carve-out that operates “subject to paragraph 7 above.” [#SRC:5550fe5863fdebc6] In addition to that general publication of the action, the PRA is required to publish information about the matters to which the relevant notice relates, and it has discretion over the manner of publication. [#TGT:3f4677fb85844f02] Practically, this means the publication decision has two linked components: (1) whether the PRA will ordinarily publish the action taken following the supervisory decision (with case-by-case consideration and the paragraph 7 qualification), and (2) the content obligation to publish information about the matters addressed by the notice, for Decision Notices and Final Notices (and also Supervisory Notices), in whatever format the PRA considers appropriate. [#SRC:5550fe5863fdebc6] [#TGT:3f4677fb85844f02] Accordingly, when preparing for potential disclosure, the PRA should ensure that its publication covers the notice-related matters (not merely the fact of action) and that the chosen publication method aligns with its discretion, while remaining consistent with its ordinary practice for Decision Notices and Final Notices. [#TGT:3f4677fb85844f02] [#SRC:5550fe5863fdebc6]
source_text: The PRA will consider the circumstances of each case, but, subject to paragraph 7 above, will ordinarily publish action in relation to supervisory decisions when this has led to the issue of a Decision Notice, as well as where it has led to the issue of a Final Notice.
target_text: Section 391 of the Act also requires the PRA to publish – in such manner as it considers appropriate – information about the matters to which a Supervisory Notice, 22 a Decision Notice, and a Final Notice relate.

question: When applying the expectations in this SS, which insurers are within scope, and how does the PRA’s supervisory framework model (as described in the March 2016 ‘PRA’s approach to insurance supervision’) support that scoping decision, particularly in light of the PRA’s view on cost impacts for smaller insurers and the risk-profile expectations for larger firms?
gold_answer: The expectations in this SS are intended to apply only to significant firms, specifically Category 1 and 2 PRA-regulated firms, rather than to all insurers. [#SRC:15dcfe5ca573a1b6] This scoping is justified by the PRA’s view that smaller insurers—often operating in a single locality or niche—would face disproportionate costs if they sought to meet the SS expectations, whereas larger firms with complex risk profiles should aim to meet or exceed those expectations when complying with regulatory requirements. [#SRC:15dcfe5ca573a1b6] The March 2016 document ‘PRA’s approach to insurance supervision’ provides the supervisory-framework linkage for this limitation by explaining that Category 1 and 2 firms are deemed significant within the PRA’s supervisory framework model. [#TGT:86a53c4da46b88c3] Read together, the SS sets the practical application boundary (significant firms only) and the March 2016 supervisory approach supplies the definitional basis for treating Category 1 and 2 firms as “significant” for that boundary. [#SRC:15dcfe5ca573a1b6] [#TGT:86a53c4da46b88c3]
source_text: The PRA takes the view that for smaller insurers (the majority of which operate in one locality or niche market) to seek to meet the expectations set out in this SS would have a disproportionate cost impact on these firms. Conversely, larger firms with complex risk profiles should seek to meet (or exceed) the PRA’s expectations as set out in this SS in complying with the regulatory requirements. The PRA therefore considers it appropriate to limit the application of the expectations as set out in this SS to significant firms only (Category 1 and 2 PRA-regulated firms). 9
