question: If an insurer is building its risk monitoring metrics and deciding what liquidity buffer(s) to hold, what does the text say the buffer is for and what kinds of things should be monitored, including how this applies to both UK Solvency II firms (and related entities) and non-Directive insurers?
gold_answer: When the insurer sets up its risk monitoring metrics and any liquidity buffer(s) it holds, the buffer should be treated as liquid assets held to help the insurer meet liabilities as they fall due, and the metrics should support monitoring that buffer. [#SRC:9c279e6bff2a8352] For a UK Solvency II firm, the Society and managing agents, the described requirement is to invest in assets that keep the investment portfolio liquid and to assess whether the assets are appropriate for paying obligations when they are due. [#TGT:69f861caa7c533e0] The guideline expectations described also point to specific monitoring topics that can be built into the metrics: the insurer should look at total liquidity needs (including an appropriate liquidity buffer), track the level and monitoring of liquid assets, and consider possible haircuts that might apply if assets have to be sold. [#TGT:69f861caa7c533e0] For a non-Directive insurer, the stated expectation is to maintain adequate liquidity so there is no significant risk of being unable to meet liabilities as they fall due, which reinforces the buffer’s purpose. [#TGT:69f861caa7c533e0] The buffer is also expected to be sufficient in both benign and stressed conditions, so monitoring should be able to reflect performance in those conditions. [#TGT:69f861caa7c533e0]
source_text: used to support the establishment of the insurer’s risk monitoring metrics and any liquidity buffer(s) held by the insurer (set out in more detail in Chapter 5 );
target_text: Under Investments 2.1 , a UK Solvency II firm, the Society and managing agents are required to invest in assets that ensure the liquidity of their investment portfolio and, under Conditions Governing Business 3.1A(4)(b) , to consider the appropriateness of their assets in order to meet obligations as they fall due. Under paragraphs 1.63(b) and (c) of EIOPA Guideline 26 an insurer should consider its total liquidity needs, including an appropriate liquidity buffer and consider the level and monitoring of liquid assets, as well as potential haircuts that could be imposed on their sale. A non-Directive insurer, under Insurance Company – Overall Resources and Valuation 2.3 or Friendly Society – Financial Prudence 4.1 must maintain adequate liquidity to ensure there is no significant risk that its liabilities cannot be met as they fall due. An insurer must therefore maintain an adequate stock of liquid assets, hereafter called a ‘liquidity buffer’, sufficient to meet liabilities as they fall due, and is expected to do so under both benign and stressed conditions.

question: If a credit union wants to sell shares inside an ISA tax-free wrapper and also wants to start offering fixed-rate shares or deposits, can it rely on HMRC approval to skip other legal requirements, and what does the PRA expect it to do before it starts the fixed-rate products?
gold_answer: No. Even if the credit union gets approval from HMRC in connection with offering shares in an ISA tax-free wrapper, that approval does not give it any exemption from complying with the statutory requirements referenced in the source passage. [#SRC:39468cc7f2d4556d] Separately, for the fixed-rate side, the PRA’s expectation is that any credit union intending to issue fixed-rate shares or deposits complies with the statutory mandatory requirements that must be met before it begins that activity. [#TGT:bb34e94b2a68af4b] Read together, the key point is that HMRC approval relates to the ISA wrapper context and does not remove statutory compliance duties, while the PRA frames statutory compliance for fixed-rate issuance as a condition that must be satisfied in advance of starting. [#SRC:39468cc7f2d4556d] [#TGT:bb34e94b2a68af4b] So the credit union should both refer to the relevant HMRC regulations for the ISA offering and ensure it has met the statutory mandatory requirements before launching fixed-rate shares or deposits, without treating HMRC approval as a substitute for those statutory obligations. [#SRC:39468cc7f2d4556d] [#TGT:bb34e94b2a68af4b]
source_text: Credit unions that wish to offer shares in an Individual Savings Account (ISA) tax-free wrapper are expected to refer to the relevant regulations issued by HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC). Credit unions should be aware that approval from HMRC does not provide any degree of exemption from compliance with the statutory requirements referred to above in paragraph 5.2 .
target_text: The PRA expects that any credit union that intends to issue fixed-rate shares or deposits complies with the statutory mandatory requirements that must be satisfied before beginning such activity. 2

question: If a company is a large subsidiary under a UK parent group (or under a parent undertaking in a third country), does it have to publish remuneration policy information, and if so, should it do it on its own or at a sub-group level and which staff does the remuneration part need to cover?
gold_answer: If the company is a large subsidiary in one of the covered structures (under UK parent institutions, UK parent financial holding companies, UK parent mixed financial holding companies, or under a parent undertaking established in a third country), it is required to disclose the information specified in the listed Articles, and it must do so either on an individual basis or on a sub-consolidated basis. [#SRC:d6dd201508b9a673] Where the disclosure includes remuneration information, the remuneration part must cover the institution’s remuneration policy and practices for the categories of staff whose professional activities have a material impact on the institution’s risk profile, so the scope is tied to risk-material staff categories rather than the entire workforce. [#TGT:d3efeb25748ccfe0] To comply, the company should first determine that it is within the “large subsidiary” scope described and then choose whether it will report at the individual entity level or at the sub-consolidated level for the required disclosures. [#TGT:d3efeb25748ccfe0] The key linkage is that the reporting basis (individual vs sub-consolidated) comes from the large-subsidiary disclosure rule, while the staff coverage for the remuneration content comes from the remuneration disclosure requirement. [#SRC:d6dd201508b9a673] [#TGT:d3efeb25748ccfe0]

question: If the transferor society(ies) and the transferee or successor society integrate their product lines and this leads to changes in the terms for PIBS 26, what is PIBS 26 and how should that affect how you describe the change?
gold_answer: You should describe the change to PIBS 26 as a change to “Permanent interest-bearing shares,” and note that this product is a type of deferred share, because that is the definition given for PIBS 26. [#TGT:91aeec4ad31299e3] The change you are describing falls within the stated scope of “any changes to the terms and conditions” for CCDS, PPDS, PIBS 26, and share and deposit accounts, and that scope explicitly includes changes connected to integrating the product lines of the transferor society(ies) into those of the transferee or successor society. [#SRC:3bbbda00879e9203] So, when integration causes PIBS 26 terms to be updated, the write-up should not treat PIBS 26 as just another account label; it should reflect that the affected item is a permanent interest-bearing share (a deferred share type) whose terms and conditions are being amended as part of the integration. question: If a derivative transaction has more than one material risk driver, what does an institution need to do so it can correctly provide the competent authorities (on request) the number of hedging sets per risk category and the risk driver information for each hedging set?
gold_answer: To be able to provide the requested hedging-set information, the institution needs to map multi-risk-driver derivative transactions to risk categories in the way required, and then report hedging sets consistently with that mapping. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] When the competent authorities ask, the institution must make available (for each risk category) the number of hedging sets it has established, plus the relevant risk driver information for each hedging set (the primary risk driver or, for the relevant transactions, the most material risk driver in that risk category, or the pair of risk drivers), and also the number of transactions in each hedging set. [#SRC:83d0ae2a5dfdf3ce] For transactions with more than one material risk driver, the institution must map them to more than one risk category, except that if all material risk drivers are in the same risk category it maps the transaction only once to that category using the most material risk driver. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] If the material risk drivers fall into different risk categories, it maps the transaction once to each relevant risk category using the most material risk driver within each category, which then supports reporting the “most material risk driver in the given risk category” alongside the hedging-set counts and transaction counts. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] [#SRC:83d0ae2a5dfdf3ce]
source_text: Institutions shall make available upon request by the competent authorities the number of hedging sets established in accordance with paragraph 2 of this Article for each risk category, with the primary risk driver, or the most material risk driver in the given risk category for transactions referred to in Article 277(3) , or the pair of risk drivers of each of those hedging sets and with the number of transactions in each of those hedging sets .
target_text: By way of derogation from paragraph 2 , institutions shall map derivative transactions that have more than one material risk driver to more than one risk category. Where all the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to the same risk category, institutions shall only be required to map that transaction once to that risk category on the basis of the most material of those risk drivers. Where the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to different risk categories, institutions shall map that transaction once to each risk category for which the transaction has at least one material risk driver, on the basis of the most material of the risk drivers in that risk category.

question: If you are checking how the PRA calculates the ultimate forward rate for a currency, what long-term expectations does it use (and when), and what kind of extra “risk add-on” is it not allowed to include?
gold_answer: To check the PRA’s calculation of the ultimate forward rate for a currency, you should confirm both what inputs it uses and what it explicitly leaves out. [#SRC:07f28fc667f26c18] [#TGT:87cfaaafc6a4804d] On the input side, for each relevant currency the ultimate forward rate takes account of expectations of the long-term real interest rate and expected inflation, but only if those expectations can be determined for that currency in a reliable manner. [#SRC:07f28fc667f26c18] On the exclusion side, the ultimate forward rate is not designed to include a term premium that would compensate for the additional risk of holding long-term investments. [#TGT:87cfaaafc6a4804d] This matters for monitoring changes over time: the PRA maintains stability in the ultimate forward rate for each relevant currency and will only change it when long-term expectations change, so you should not expect changes that are driven by adding (or adjusting) a term premium. [#SRC:07f28fc667f26c18] The PRA also uses the same methodology as that specified by EIOPA in its Report on the Calculation of the UFR for 2024, so your review should align to that methodological approach while still confirming the “no term premium” feature. [#SRC:07f28fc667f26c18] [#TGT:87cfaaafc6a4804d]
source_text: For each relevant currency the ultimate forward rate takes account of expectations of the long-term real interest rate and expected inflation, provided those expectations can be determined for that currency in a reliable manner. The PRA will maintain stability in the ultimate forward rate for each relevant currency and will only make changes where there are changes in long-term expectations. The PRA uses the same methodology as that specified by EIOPA in its Report on the Calculation of the UFR for 2024. 4
target_text: The ultimate forward rate does not include a term premium to reflect the additional risk of holding long-term investments.

question: If an Institution has a contractual netting agreement, when can it use one exposure value for all the transactions, and what does it need to tell the competent authorities if it starts or stops using the method it uses to calculate exposure values for its derivative positions?
gold_answer: An Institution can use one combined exposure value for all transactions inside a contractual netting agreement only if all the conditions in Article 274(1) are met. [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c] If those conditions are not met, the Institution must calculate an exposure value for each transaction separately, and each transaction is treated as its own netting set. [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c] Separately from choosing between a combined or separate calculation outcome, the Institution has a notification duty tied to the calculation methods it uses for exposure values of derivative positions: it must notify the competent authorities of the methods in Section 4 or 5 that it uses, or that it ceases to use, as applicable. [#SRC:7085c26bac1b91bb] Putting these together, if the Institution changes how it calculates exposure values for derivative positions—such as moving from separate transaction exposure values to a single exposure value under a contractual netting agreement (or the reverse)—it should ensure that the competent authorities are notified about the relevant Section 4 or 5 method being adopted or discontinued, while the permissibility of a single exposure value depends on meeting all Article 274(1) conditions. [#SRC:7085c26bac1b91bb] [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c]
source_text: Institutions shall notify the competent authorities of the methods set out in Section 4 or 5 that they use, or cease to use, as applicable, to calculate the exposure value of their derivative positions.
target_text: Institutions may calculate a single exposure value for all the transactions within a contractual netting agreement where all the conditions set out in Article 274(1) are met. Otherwise, institutions shall calculate an exposure value separately for each transaction, which shall be treated as its own netting set.

question: If a derivative has several important risk drivers and at least one of them puts it in the commodity risk category, when do you map it to more than one risk category, and how do you then pick the risk driver to place it into a commodity hedging set (including for transactions referred to in Article 277(3))?
gold_answer: You must handle the mapping step first, and then use the commodity-specific rule to place the transaction into a hedging set once it is in the commodity risk category. [#SRC:820ffbb74005c855] If the derivative has more than one material risk driver, you generally map it to more than one risk category. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] However, if all of its material risk drivers are within the same risk category, you only map it once to that single category, and you base that mapping on the most material of those risk drivers. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] If its material risk drivers sit in different risk categories, you map it once to each risk category where it has at least one material risk driver, and for each category you use the most material risk driver within that category as the basis for the mapping. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] Once the transaction is mapped to the commodity risk category (including transactions referred to in Article 277(3)), you must assign it to one of the commodity hedging sets based on the nature of its primary risk driver, or (for those Article 277(3) transactions) the most material risk driver in the commodity risk category. [#SRC:820ffbb74005c855]

Where the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to different risk categories, institutions shall map that transaction once to each risk category for which the transaction has at least one material risk driver, on the basis of the most material of the risk drivers in that risk category.

question: For a firm that is a parent entity of an international group, what does the PRA expect the firm to show in its group recovery plan regarding (i) coverage of entities in other jurisdictions and (ii) the way dependencies and mutual exclusivity between recovery options are identified and explained?
gold_answer: A firm that is a parent entity of an international group should produce a group recovery plan that both (1) evidences coverage of group entities located in other jurisdictions and (2) provides a clear, structured explanation of how recovery options depend on one another, including where options cannot be used together. [#TGT:87b9b2ff210e1f41] In practice, the plan should demonstrate how different entities in other jurisdictions are addressed within the group recovery plan, rather than leaving their treatment implicit. [#TGT:87b9b2ff210e1f41] Alongside that jurisdictional coverage, the PRA expects the firm to detail and explain dependencies between recovery options and to clearly flag any recovery options that are mutually exclusive. [#SRC:21e8b786b13431f6] The dependency analysis should be framed to help the firm understand dependencies between group entities, including both financial and non-financial dependencies, so that the interaction of recovery actions is transparent in a cross-border group context. [#TGT:87b9b2ff210e1f41] The firm should therefore link its explanation of recovery-option dependencies and mutual exclusivity to the way it has covered different entities across jurisdictions, so the plan shows how those inter-entity dependencies affect which recovery options can be executed and in what combinations. [#SRC:21e8b786b13431f6] [#TGT:87b9b2ff210e1f41]
source_text: The PRA expects firms to detail and explain the dependencies between recovery options and clearly identify where recovery options are mutually exclusive (the interaction between recovery options at group and subsidiary levels is covered under ‘ (xi) Interaction between group and subsidiary plans ’ below).
target_text: The PRA expects firms that are parent entities of an international group to demonstrate how they have covered different entities in other jurisdictions in their group recovery plan. It is important for firms to understand dependencies, both financial and non-financial, between group entities.

question: If an institution is working out its risk-weighted exposure amounts for trade exposures with CCPs (for Article 92(3)), what steps does it follow, and which sections/chapters tell it how to calculate the exposure values before it applies the risk weight?
gold_answer: To calculate risk-weighted exposure amounts for trade exposures with CCPs for Article 92(3), an institution must start by calculating the exposure values for its CCP trade exposures, then add those exposure values together, and then multiply the total by the relevant risk weight. [#SRC:99cd1305ee2e0e40] The exposure values used in that total must be calculated using the specified framework: Sections 1 to 8 of the Chapter and, where applicable, Section 4 of Chapter 4. [#TGT:325217a9dca51ff6] The source text also makes clear that, for this risk-weighted exposure amount calculation, the exposure values are those calculated under the paragraph-based method referenced for exposure values (paragraphs 2 and 3), and the risk weight applied is the one determined under the referenced paragraph 1. [#SRC:99cd1305ee2e0e40] Putting these together, the institution should not skip directly to applying a risk weight; it must first compute exposure values under the required Sections/Chapter approach (and the referenced paragraph method), sum them across its CCP trade exposures, and only then apply the risk weight to that sum to arrive at the risk-weighted exposure amounts. [#SRC:99cd1305ee2e0e40] [#TGT:325217a9dca51ff6]
source_text: An institution shall calculate the risk-weighted exposure amounts for its trade exposures with CCPs for the purposes of Article 92(3) as the sum of the exposure values of its trade exposures with CCPs, calculated in accordance with paragraphs 2 and 3 of this Article, multiplied by the risk weight determined in accordance with paragraph 1 of this Article.
target_text: An institution shall calculate exposure values of its trade exposures with a CCP in accordance with Sections 1 to 8 of this Chapter and with Section 4 of Chapter 4, as applicable.

question: If a credit union has more than £10 million in total assets and also does additional activities that involve more complex investments (like supranational bonds or money market funds), what does it need to do about its investment policy, and what does the PRA expect about concentration limits (including any exception mentioned)?
gold_answer: In this situation, the credit union is expected to address both internal governance and portfolio concentration, because the passages describe expectations that apply to (a) credit unions over £10 million in assets and (b) credit unions investing in more complex investments or undertaking additional activities. question: When assessing whether a credit institution’s arrangements, strategies, processes and mechanisms, together with its own funds and liquidity, ensure sound management and coverage of its risks under the PRA’s review and evaluation in Regulation 34A(2) of the Capital Requirements Regulations 2013, how does the PRA’s stated approach for STS ABCP sponsor status affect the likelihood of a positive determination, and what specific sponsor status condition is highlighted (including how non-STS programmes are treated)?
gold_answer: A positive PRA determination under the Regulation 34A(2) review and evaluation is framed as a finding that the credit institution’s arrangements, strategies, processes and mechanisms, together with the own funds and liquidity it holds, provide for sound management and coverage of its risks. [#SRC:b99fc6e0f4b4c219] However, for the specific purpose of being an STS ABCP sponsor, the PRA indicates it is unlikely to reach that positive determination unless an additional condition about the firm’s current sponsorship position is met. [#TGT:1ed088c2d925583a] In practice, this means: - The baseline determination concerns whether the institution’s implemented risk arrangements and its own funds and liquidity are sufficient to manage and cover risks, as assessed via the Regulation 34A(2) review and evaluation. [#SRC:b99fc6e0f4b4c219] - For STS ABCP sponsor purposes, the PRA is unlikely to make that determination unless the firm is currently a sponsor for at least one ABCP programme. [#TGT:1ed088c2d925583a] - The PRA’s stated condition can be satisfied by an existing non-STS ABCP programme where the firm wishes to seek STS status for that programme. [#TGT:1ed088c2d925583a] Accordingly, even where the Regulation 34A(2) assessment focuses on risk arrangements and financial resources, the PRA’s STS ABCP sponsor approach adds a current-sponsorship threshold that affects the likelihood of a favourable determination. [#SRC:b99fc6e0f4b4c219] [#TGT:1ed088c2d925583a]
source_text: (ii) the PRA has determined on the basis of the review and evaluation referred to in Regulation 34A(2) of the Capital Requirements Regulations 2013 that the arrangements, strategies, processes, and mechanisms implemented by that credit institution and the own funds and liquidity it holds ensure the sound management and coverage of its risks ( SECN 2.3.25R(2) of the FCA Handbook ).
target_text: For the purposes of being an STS ABCP sponsor , the PRA is unlikely to determine on the basis of the review and evaluation referred to in Regulation 34A(2) of the Capital Requirements Regulations 2013 that the arrangements, strategies, processes, and mechanisms implemented by that credit institution and the own funds and liquidity it holds ensure the sound management and coverage of its risks, unless the firm is currently a sponsor for at least one ABCP programme. This may include any existing non-STS ABCP programme for which the firm wishes to seek STS status.

question: When a controller or proposed controller that is an investment manager is following the directions in 2.1 and 2.3 for an acquisition or disposal of listed shares in the course of its fund management activity, how should the content and accompanying documents of the section 178 notice be determined, and which form may be used for that notice?
gold_answer: In this scenario, the section 178 notice must be prepared by reference to the Controller’s Form requirements, and the investment manager may use the specific Controller’s form identified by the PRA for this context. [#SRC:3d54441b14fbefda] Consistently, the PRA directs that a section 178 notice submitted in accordance with section 178(1) of FSMA must contain the information and be accompanied by the documents required by the Controller’s Form approved for the relevant application. question: For a firm that carries on both long-term insurance business and general insurance business, how should the obligation to maintain a margin of solvency at or above the required margin be applied—does it operate as a single combined margin or as separate margins for each kind of business, and how does the “Subject to 2.3” qualifier affect the statement of that obligation?
gold_answer: A firm that carries on both long-term insurance business and general insurance business must treat the margin-of-solvency obligation as applying separately to each kind of business, rather than as a single combined margin across both lines. [#SRC:a1a38574845ced8b] In other words, when applying the rule that a firm must maintain a margin of solvency equal to or greater than the required margin of solvency, the firm should read that requirement as two parallel requirements—one margin in respect of long-term insurance business and another margin in respect of general insurance business. [#SRC:a1a38574845ced8b][#TGT:a6802aa70f056690] The baseline obligation in the rule is framed as mandatory (“must maintain”) and is expressed by reference to the required margin of solvency, but it is expressly qualified by the opening condition “Subject to 2.3,” meaning the stated obligation is not absolute in all circumstances and is applied within that stated qualification. [#TGT:a6802aa70f056690] Separately, the rule’s scope excludes a “flat rate benefits business friendly society” from the stated obligation, so the described requirement (and its separate-margin application for dual-business firms) is directed at firms other than that excluded category. [#TGT:a6802aa70f056690]
source_text: Where a firm carries on both long-term insurance business and general insurance business , 2.1 has effect as if the requirement to maintain a margin of solvency were a requirement to maintain separate margins in respect of the two kinds of business.
target_text: Subject to 2.3 , a firm (other than a flat rate benefits business friendly society ) must maintain a margin of solvency equal to or greater than the required margin of solvency .

question: Where a firm has established a specific, independent and autonomous internal channel for disclosure of reportable concerns, what must the firm do to ensure that workers in a third country firm’s UK establishment can use that channel, and what information must be provided to the third country firm in the UK?
gold_answer: The firm must both (i) have an internal disclosure channel that meets the required characteristics and (ii) ensure that this channel is operationally extended to the relevant UK establishment of the third country firm, with appropriate information provided to enable use. [#TGT:e1060de75b1384d6] Specifically, the firm is required to establish, implement and maintain arrangements that allow a person (including a firm’s employee) to disclose reportable concerns internally via a channel that is specific, independent and autonomous. [#TGT:e1060de75b1384d6] In addition, the firm must provide information to the third country firm in the UK about the channel identified in 2A.2, and it must make that channel available to workers in the third country firm’s UK establishment. [#SRC:ac7d95fab418408e] Taken together, this means the firm cannot treat the internal channel as limited to its own direct employees: it must ensure the channel is available for use by workers in the third country firm’s UK establishment and must communicate the necessary channel information to the third country firm in the UK so that disclosures of reportable concerns can be made through that internal channel. [#SRC:ac7d95fab418408e] [#TGT:e1060de75b1384d6]
source_text: the firm must provide information to the third country firm in the UK on the channel in 2A.2 and make the channel available to workers in the third country firm’s UK establishment.
target_text: (1) A firm must establish, implement and maintain appropriate and effective arrangements for the disclosure of reportable concerns by a person , including a firm’s employee , internally through a specific, independent and autonomous channel.

question: If a credit union does extra activities or has over 15,000 members, can it just use the Table 1 percentages as-is to monitor the business? Also, what does the PRA mean when it says the Table 1 percentages are a “prudent practice” example for everything except loans-to-assets?
gold_answer: No—while Table 1 provides indicative ratios, the credit union is expected to monitor its relevant business using ratios with values calibrated to its own business model, not simply adopted unchanged. [#SRC:5983e59e8a0d7466] The credit union should also have measures to set its tolerance for triggers and ratios that support resilience, and the board is expected to judge which ratios and values best reflect what matters most and the risks in the organisation. [#SRC:5983e59e8a0d7466] At the same time, the PRA gives an example of what it views as prudent practice: for credit unions that undertake additional activities or have more than 15,000 members, the PRA considers the indicative ratio percentages in Table 1 to be prudent for all calculations other than loans to assets. [#TGT:76fa69d28babf150] This means Table 1 can serve as a benchmark for most ratio calculations, but the credit union still needs to choose values that provide an accurate and reliable tool for the board to monitor performance against the strategic plan and regulatory obligations. [#SRC:5983e59e8a0d7466] The credit union should also be able to explain and evidence its chosen ratios and the rationale for them if asked, including how it handled the loans-to-assets carve-out when considering Table 1 percentages. [#SRC:5983e59e8a0d7466] [#TGT:76fa69d28babf150]
source_text: A credit union that is undertaking ‘additional activities’ 1 (see Table 1) or that has more than 15,000 members, and is therefore subject to the requirement in Rule 10.3(3) of the Credit Unions Part of the PRA Rulebook, is expected to monitor its relevant business by using the ratios in paragraph 4.3 below, calibrated with values that are specifically aligned to its individual business model. Credit unions should have measures that help them define their tolerance for triggers and ratios that underpin their resilience. The ratios in table 1 below are indicative; the PRA expects boards to assess what is most important and reflects the risks in their organisation. The PRA expects the values selected by the credit union to provide an accurate and reliable business tool, by which its board may routinely and accurately monitor the credit union’s performance against its strategic plan and its regulatory obligations. The PRA also expects the credit union to be able to provide details of its chosen ratios, and evidence of the rationale underlying them, on request.

question: If the PRA puts off a class A2 member’s recapitalisation payment levy share because paying now would harm the firm’s liquidity or solvency, how long can that delay last, can it be extended, and when does the firm have to pay the deferred amount?
gold_answer: The deferred amount has to be paid when paying it no longer puts the firm’s liquidity and solvency at risk, and the PRA’s deferral cannot last more than six months at a time, although it can be renewed if the firm requests it. [#SRC:f026573295165d20] [#TGT:9b64fbbd8245427b] In other words, the payment timing is linked to the firm’s financial condition: once the payment would not jeopardise liquidity and solvency, the contribution becomes due. [#SRC:f026573295165d20] The PRA can defer the obligation (fully or partly) only where it considers the contribution would jeopardise the liquidity or solvency of the firm, and this applies to a class A2 member’s share of a recapitalisation payment levy. [#TGT:9b64fbbd8245427b] The six-month limit is a hard cap on any single deferral period, but the firm can ask for a renewal, which allows the deferral to continue beyond six months through renewed periods. [#TGT:9b64fbbd8245427b] So the firm should track both (i) whether the liquidity/solvency risk has ended (which triggers payment) and (ii) the end date of the current six-month deferral period (which may require a renewal request). [#SRC:f026573295165d20] [#TGT:9b64fbbd8245427b]
source_text: Any contributions deferred pursuant to 46.2 or 46.2A shall be paid when the payment no longer jeopardises the liquidity and solvency of the firm .
target_text: The PRA may defer, in whole or in part, a class A2 member’s obligation to pay a share of a recapitalisation payment levy if the PRA considers that such contributions would jeopardise the liquidity or solvency of the firm . Such deferral shall not be granted for a longer period than six months but may be renewed upon request of the firm .

question: For UK subsidiaries of groups based outside of the UK, how should the recovery plan be structured for usability by boards and business areas, and what additional steps should the firm take regarding UK playbooks where the PRA may request more detailed work as part of UK recovery planning?
gold_answer: A UK subsidiary of a group based outside the UK should structure its recovery plan so it is readily usable by both the board and the specific business areas that would need to use it, because the board must be able to navigate and understand the plan quickly in order to take key decisions during a stress. [#TGT:a3cffd0082b9333d] In addition, such UK subsidiaries should consider the guidance on fire drills and playbooks referenced in Chapter 2 (vi) and (vii), and treat this as relevant input when shaping the plan’s practical usability for decision-makers and users. [#SRC:f4ab9388eafb627e] Where the PRA explicitly asks the firm to undertake more detailed work on UK playbooks as part of its UK recovery planning work, the firm should engage with that request and contact its supervisor to discuss whether this applies to it. [#SRC:f4ab9388eafb627e] Taken together, this means the firm should (i) design the recovery plan’s structure to support rapid board navigation and comprehension and to be workable for the business areas that will execute it, and (ii) be prepared to deepen UK playbook work—aligned to the referenced fire drill/playbook guidance—when the PRA signals that more detailed UK playbook work is expected. [#TGT:a3cffd0082b9333d] [#SRC:f4ab9388eafb627e]
source_text: (vii) UK subsidiaries of groups based outside of the UK should also consider the guidance on fire drills and playbooks set out in Chapter 2 (vi) and (vii) . In some cases, the PRA may explicitly ask firms to undertake more detailed work on UK playbooks as part of their UK recovery planning work. Firms should contact their supervisor to discuss whether this applies.
target_text: The PRA expects recovery plans to be structured so that they are readily usable by both boards and the specific business areas of firms that would need to use them. It is important that the board can quickly navigate and understand the recovery plan as they will be taking the key decisions in a stress.

question: If a firm is reapplying the floor methodology and calibration referenced in Matching Adjustment 4.11 to 4.15 for stressed FS, but some of the data referred to in 4.13(4) is missing or unreliable, how may the firm proceed while still meeting the PRA’s expectations on justification and minimum calibration outcomes?
gold_answer: A firm may address missing or unreliable inputs for the data referred to in 4.13(4) by using constructed data, but it must do so in a way that preserves the PRA’s minimum expectations for the floor used in stressed FS modelling. [#SRC:c25a4960dc77cc1d] Specifically, the PRA expects the firm to maintain a floor (a minimum level of FS at the appropriate point in the calculation) based on long-term average spreads and, at a minimum, to reapply the methodology and calibration for that floor as set out in Matching Adjustment 4.11 to 4.15. [#SRC:c25a4960dc77cc1d] Where the 4.13(4) data is not available or not reliable, the firm may use constructed data based on prudent assumptions, but that constructed data must be anchored in available and reliable data relating to the previous 30 years. [#TGT:5f5585242ebb290e] If the firm makes any changes to the floor (including changes driven by the use of constructed data), the PRA expects those changes to be justified. [#SRC:c25a4960dc77cc1d] In addition, the firm should ensure that any such changes do not produce a calibration below what would have resulted from reapplying the methodology and calibration used to calculate the TPs, so the constructed-data approach should be designed and evidenced to avoid lowering the floor beneath that minimum outcome. [#SRC:c25a4960dc77cc1d]
source_text: The PRA expects firms to maintain a floor (ie a minimum level of FS at the appropriate point of the calculation) based on long-term average spreads as part of their modelling of the stressed FS. As a minimum, the PRA expects firms to reapply the methodology and calibration of the floor as set out in Matching Adjustment 4.11 to 4.15 . If any changes are made to the floor, the PRA expects these changes to be justified. They should not result in a calibration below that which would have been obtained by re-applying the methodology and calibration used to calculate the TPs.
target_text: Where part of the data referred to in 4.13(4) is not available or where the available data is not reliable, constructed data based on prudent assumptions may be used; and the constructed data must be based on available and reliable data relating to the previous 30 years.

question: For a TWD firm forecasting the impact of a TWD scenario from the reference date of the TWD option through the wind-down period, what specific categories of information and analytical capabilities must be in place so that the firm can both project impacts on capital requirements/resources/liquidity and perform the required financial impact projections and sensitivity analysis, including portfolio segmentation for alternative packaging of trades for novation?

question: When calculating the solvency of a group, how must the proportional share held by the participating undertaking be applied to data from related undertakings linked by a common management relationship, and how does this interact with the instruction that this inclusion applies notwithstanding point (4) of 11.1A and must follow points (1), (3), (4), (5) or (6) of 11.1A?
gold_answer: In calculating the solvency of a group, the calculation must reflect the proportional share held by the participating undertaking in its related undertakings, and that proportional-share approach is also the basis for including data from related undertakings that are linked by a common management relationship. [#TGT:acc84032d208c7bc] [#SRC:477b207547388eb5] Practically, this means that where the group’s solvency calculation needs to take account of related undertakings, the participating undertaking’s proportional share is the measure used to determine the extent to which those related undertakings are reflected in the group calculation. [#TGT:acc84032d208c7bc] For related undertakings linked by a common management relationship, their data must be included using that proportional-share basis, and the inclusion is to be carried out in line with points (1), (3), (4), (5) or (6) of 11.1A rather than being excluded or altered due to point (4) of 11.1A. [#SRC:477b207547388eb5] The linkage is that the group solvency calculation’s requirement to take account of proportional share is implemented, for common-management related undertakings, through the specific instruction to include their data proportionally and to do so under the specified points of 11.1A even where point (4) of 11.1A might otherwise be relevant. [#TGT:acc84032d208c7bc] [#SRC:477b207547388eb5]
source_text: Notwithstanding point (4) of 11.1A data of related undertakings linked by a common management relationship shall be included in accordance with points (1), (3), (4), (5) or (6) of 11.1A on the basis of the proportional share as referred to in Chapter 8 .
target_text: The calculation of the solvency of a group must take account of the proportional share held by the participating undertaking in its related undertakings .

question: For a firm within scope of the PRA’s booking-arrangements expectations, how should the bank reflect its chosen booking model in contingency planning for winding down trading books, and how does the PRA’s proportional application of those expectations interact with the potential resolution impediments described for a global booking model under an MPE strategy?
gold_answer: A bank that is within the scope of the PRA’s booking-arrangements expectations should ensure that its contingency plans for winding down trading books in a solvent and orderly manner explicitly incorporate the implications of the booking model it has adopted, because the PRA expects the booking model to be fully taken into account in those plans. [#TGT:9fcb3c210c05859d] This planning focus sits alongside the PRA’s statement that it will apply the booking-arrangements expectations proportionately to the level of investment banking or sales and trading activity the firm undertakes, meaning the depth and intensity of the bank’s implementation should be calibrated to that activity profile. [#SRC:8a9b8ceafce61236] In practice, where the bank uses a global booking model, it should treat the model’s group inter-connectivity as a factor that can complicate post-resolution restructuring and, under a multiple-point-of-entry strategy, can become an impediment to resolution that the bank should address through its planning. [#TGT:9fcb3c210c05859d] The proportionality principle does not remove the need to address those model-driven risks; rather, it frames how extensively the bank evidences and operationalises the integration of booking-model considerations into wind-down and resolution-related contingency plans, in line with its investment banking or sales and trading footprint. [#SRC:8a9b8ceafce61236]
source_text: The expectations of a firm’s booking arrangements set out in this section are applicable to all international banks and UK trading banks. Paragraphs 4.24A - 4.25Z and 4.25AE are applicable to both types of bank, paragraphs 4.25AA - 4.25AD are applicable only to international banks [see para 1.1 ]. The PRA will apply these expectations in a manner that is proportionate to the level of investment banking or sales and trading activity that the firm undertakes.
target_text: While a global booking model may not be considered a direct impediment under a single point of entry resolution strategy, it could add complexity to the restructuring of the group post resolution. Under a multiple-point-of-entry (MPE) strategy, the inter-connectivity between the UK authorised firm and the group associated to a global booking could be an impediment to resolution that the bank should address. 40 Similarly, where contingency plans to be able to wind down trading books in a solvent and orderly fashion are important to any orderly exit, recovery, or resolution strategy, the PRA expects that the particular booking model adopted by a bank will have been fully taken into account in those plans.

question: When a firm validates its internal credit assessment methodology and criteria for Matching Adjustment purposes, how must that validation connect (i) identification and allowance for all sources of credit risk and (ii) the requirement that internal credit assessment outcomes fall within a CRA’s plausible range and show broad consistency and no bias at asset-type and portfolio levels?
gold_answer: A firm’s validation should be designed to demonstrate both methodological soundness and outcome comparability, so that the PRA can be satisfied the internal credit assessment process is appropriately validated and produces results consistent with the CRA-based benchmarks described for Matching Adjustment. The PRA expects validation to cover the firm’s internal credit assessment methodology and criteria, including how the firm has identified and allowed for all sources of credit risk, whether using qualitative or quantitative approaches. [#SRC:4f0228446ac0d767] In addition, the validation should ensure the internal credit assessment outcomes meet the relevant outcome-focused expectations, which include being within the plausible range of issue ratings that could have resulted from a CRA and showing broad consistency and no bias versus CRA issue ratings at both the asset type and portfolio level. [#TGT:5fd5739308652721] Practically, this means the firm should not treat validation as only a model-governance exercise; it must also test whether outputs align with the plausible CRA range and are broadly consistent and unbiased across assets and the portfolio. [#TGT:5fd5739308652721] The PRA also expects the validation to ensure outcomes satisfy the points referenced in paragraph 2.4, linking the validation work to those outcome checks. [#SRC:4f0228446ac0d767] While CRA sample assessments can help evidence broad consistency, the firm should avoid solely or mechanistically relying on credit ratings when assessing creditworthiness. [#TGT:5fd5739308652721]
source_text: The PRA expects that, as part of the requirement for a firm to have an internal credit assessment process that is subject to appropriate validation as per Matching Adjustment 7.2(4) , the firm will have validated its internal credit assessment methodology and criteria, including how it has identified and allowed for all sources of credit risk, whether qualitatively or quantitatively. In addition, the PRA expects the firm’s validation to ensure that the internal credit assessment outcomes have satisfied the points in paragraph 2.4 above.
target_text: [First sentence moved to 2.4B ] As part of demonstrating that internal credit assessments are of a comparable standard to a credit rating as per Matching Adjustment 7.1(1) , Matching Adjustment 7.2(2) requires that internal credit assessment outcomes lie within the plausible range of issue ratings that could have resulted from a CRA. Matching Adjustment 7.2(3) also requires broad consistency and no bias within the plausible range between firms’ internal credit assessment outcomes and CRA issue ratings at an asset type and the portfolio level. These requirements will help to give the PRA some assurance that the basic FS is appropriate. Having sample assets assessed by a CRA will additionally help demonstrate broad consistency between a firm’s internal credit assessment outcomes and comparable CRA issue ratings. Nevertheless, firms should not solely or mechanistically rely on credit ratings for assessing the creditworthiness of an entity or financial instrument. 12

question: If you need the profit number to work out the ‘relevant amount’ for equity shares (11.6), which year’s profits do you use and what kind of accounts must those profits come from under 11.7, especially if the issuer’s accounts are not made under Accounts Directives rules?
gold_answer: For equity shares, the ‘relevant amount’ for the purposes of 11.6 is based on the issuer’s profits after taxation from its ordinary activities for the most recent financial year that ends on or before the valuation date. [#SRC:a2a19cd5ab3c2b3f] Those profits must be taken from accounts that are publicly available and reported in accounts prepared in accordance with 11.8, and the amount used must be limited to what is attributable to the equity shares while also reflecting any changes caused by alterations in capital structure. [#SRC:a2a19cd5ab3c2b3f] Separately, for the purposes of 11.7, the issuer’s profits after taxation from its ordinary activities for the relevant financial year must be derived from accounts drawn up under legislation implementing the Accounts Directives. [#TGT:68f79027ccb9b6a3] If the issuer’s accounts are not drawn up under that Accounts Directives legislation, then the profits must instead be derived from accounts drawn up in accordance with International Accounting Standards Committee accounting standards or US generally accepted accounting practice. [#TGT:68f79027ccb9b6a3] Putting these together, you select the valuation-date-linked year and apply the equity-share attribution and capital-structure adjustment from 11.6, but you also ensure the profit figure is derived from accounts prepared under one of the accounting bases permitted by 11.7. [#SRC:a2a19cd5ab3c2b3f] [#TGT:68f79027ccb9b6a3]
source_text: For the purposes of 11.6 , the ‘relevant amount’ in relation to equity shares is the issuer’s profits after taxation from its ordinary activities for the most recent financial year ending on or before the valuation date which is reported in accounts in accordance with 11.8 which are publicly available, in so far as attributable to those equity shares , taking account of the effect of any alterations in capital structure.
target_text: For the purposes of 11.7 , the issuer’s profits after taxation from its ordinary activities for the relevant financial year must be derived from accounts drawn up in accordance with legislation implementing the Accounts Directives or, if accounts are not so drawn up, from accounts drawn up in accordance with International Accounting Standards Committee accounting standards or US generally accepted accounting practice.

question: If you work at a third-country branch undertaking in the UK, where do you look for (1) the PRA rules that apply to you and (2) the extra PRA expectations you’re expected to refer to, and how does this connect to the PRA’s focus on ‘supervisability’?
gold_answer: You should use two complementary sources: the PRA Rulebook for the applicable rules, and the Prudential and Resolution Policy Index for the additional rules and expectations the PRA expects third country branches to refer to, and you should organise your compliance work so it supports the PRA’s assessment of ‘supervisability’ and regulatory equivalence. [#SRC:b3cd6bbde42a8501] First, because third-country branch undertakings operating in the UK are subject to the PRA’s rules that are relevant to third-country branches and third-country branch undertakings, you should identify and track those requirements in the PRA Rulebook. [#SRC:b3cd6bbde42a8501] Second, for further details of PRA rules and expectations the PRA expects third country branches to refer to, you should consult the listed sections of the Prudential and Resolution Policy Index, specifically the pages covering third-country branches of international insurers, Cross-cutting policies, Run Off and Undertakings in Difficulty, and Policyholder Protection. [#TGT:3b54c4e703c83d05] Linking these sources matters because the PRA’s authorisation and supervision approach for third-country branches is anchored in its statutory objectives and is underpinned by the PRA’s assessment of regulatory equivalence and its ability to effectively supervise a branch insurer (its ‘supervisability’). [#SRC:b3cd6bbde42a8501]
source_text: The PRA’s approach to the authorisation and supervision of third-country branches is anchored in its statutory objectives. The principles of this approach are set out in further detail in Section 2 and are underpinned by the PRA’s assessment of regulatory equivalence and ‘supervisability’, which is the PRA’s ability to effectively supervise an insurer that seeks to operate in the UK through a branch. question: When the PRA conducts an equivalence assessment for the purposes of authorisation and supervision, how should it frame that assessment in terms of (i) the outcomes and consistency with the UK regulatory framework, and (ii) the separation between the PRA’s own assessment and any advice it may provide to HM Treasury under Regulation 4 of SI 2019/541?
gold_answer: The PRA should treat its equivalence assessment as an outcomes-focused, PRA-specific judgement used to support the PRA’s own authorisation and supervision functions, while keeping that assessment distinct from any advice it may separately provide to HM Treasury for HM Treasury’s equivalence determinations made for other purposes. [#TGT:b4c97c646d738581] In forming the PRA’s own overall assessment, the PRA evaluates whether the home state supervisor is sufficiently equivalent and whether the home state regime aligns with the UK regulatory framework in delivering appropriate outcomes that meet the PRA’s objectives. [#SRC:8e5451c44f63e11a] The PRA assesses the relevant factors in the round, but it gives considerable weight to the extent and quality of co-operation with the home state supervisor, and it also considers supervision at both the individual-firm level (including branches) and at the consolidated group level, taking into account the nature and scale of the firm’s UK activities. [#SRC:8e5451c44f63e11a] Separately, the PRA may provide advice to HM Treasury pursuant to Regulation 4 of The Equivalence Determinations for Financial Services and Miscellaneous Provisions (Amendment etc.) (EU Exit) Regulations 2019 (SI 2019/541), but that advisory role does not convert the PRA’s authorisation-and-supervision assessment into HM Treasury’s determination process. [#TGT:b4c97c646d738581]
source_text: The PRA will make an overall assessment of whether the home state supervisor is sufficiently equivalent, and whether its regime is consistent with the UK regulatory framework in delivering appropriate outcomes that meet the PRA’s objectives. 9 The PRA assesses these factors in their totality, but will place considerable weight on assessing the extent and quality of co-operation with the home state supervisor. The PRA will take into account the supervision of individual firms (including branches) and their consolidated group, and it will consider the nature and scale of a firm’s activities in the UK.
target_text: 9. The PRA’s assessment of equivalence is based on the outcomes achieved and is for the purposes of authorisation and supervision by the PRA, which is separate from advice the PRA may provide to HM Treasury where HM Treasury may make determinations of equivalence for other purposes. The PRA may give advice to HM Treasury pursuant to Regulation 4 of The Equivalence Determinations for Financial Services and Miscellaneous Provisions (Amendment etc.) (EU Exit) Regulations 2019 (SI 2019/541).

question: If a firm has to follow the PRA’s recovery planning rules and wants to use the TWD option, what does it need to include in its recovery plan and which document explains how SS9/17 links with other PRA policies and this SS for that option?
gold_answer: The firm needs a recovery plan that contains a range of executable options, and the TWD option can be one of those options because it is a recovery option. [#SRC:79cc8d3f5662f4d8] Since the TWD option is a recovery option, the expectations in SS9/17 apply to it. [#TGT:cdec50384b35267e] When building or updating the recovery plan, the firm should therefore ensure the TWD option is developed in a way that reflects SS9/17’s recovery planning expectations, including expectations covering governance, information and reporting requirements, and the use of fire drills and playbooks. [#SRC:79cc8d3f5662f4d8] To understand how those SS9/17 expectations should be read alongside other relevant PRA policies and alongside this SS specifically for the TWD option, the firm should look to the document that sets out that interaction. [#TGT:cdec50384b35267e] The interaction between SS9/17, other relevant PRA policies, and this SS is described in the PRA’s Trading activity wind-down Statement of Policy (SoP). [#TGT:cdec50384b35267e]
source_text: All firms subject to the PRA’s recovery planning rules are required to have a recovery plan containing a range of executable options. SS9/17 sets out expectations for recovery planning relating to governance, information and reporting requirements, fire drills and playbooks, amongst other areas. 7

question: How should a bank incorporate the possibility that the Bank may change its preferred resolution strategy into its forward planning, specifically in relation to anticipating when it will come into scope of operational continuity in resolution (OCIR) and identifying where OCIR sits in the PRA Rulebook?
gold_answer: A bank should treat growth-driven changes in the Bank’s preferred resolution strategy as a forward-planning trigger to anticipate when it will newly fall within the scope of additional resolvability-related policies, and then plan an orderly transition to meet them in advance. [#SRC:782c0514fa3d2263] In particular, because the Bank may shift its preferred resolution strategy to a partial transfer or a bail-in resolution strategy as the bank grows, the bank should proactively assess when that shift could occur and when it would therefore come into scope of operational continuity in resolution (OCIR). [#SRC:782c0514fa3d2263] The bank should also ensure it can locate and use the relevant rule source for OCIR by referencing the Operational Continuity Part of the PRA Rulebook (available at the specified PRA Rulebook link). [#TGT:bde23c337e322fa8] As part of this approach, the bank should remain aware of the PRA’s and the Bank’s Resolvability Assessment Framework (RAF) and use that awareness to inform its forward planning and transition work. [#SRC:782c0514fa3d2263] The practical compliance outcome is that the bank plans well in advance for the point at which OCIR becomes applicable and prepares to transition to meet OCIR expectations by using the Operational Continuity Part as the rulebook anchor for that policy area. [#SRC:782c0514fa3d2263] [#TGT:bde23c337e322fa8]
source_text: As a bank grows, the Bank can change its preferred resolution strategy to either a partial transfer or a bail-in resolution strategy. Banks should be aware of the PRA’s and the Bank’s Resolvability Assessment Framework (RAF) and, as part of their forward planning, anticipate when their preferred resolution strategy may change and when they will come into scope of different policies, for example the MREL 70 or operational continuity in resolution (OCIR). 71 72 Banks should plan for this well in advance and consider how they will transition to meet these policies.
target_text: 72. Operational Continuity Part of the PRA Rulebook: http://www.prarulebook.co.uk/rulebook/Content/Part/320890 .

question: When making an application to the PRA for approval of a Schedule 16 Statement, how should the board’s declaration address other merger or takeover proposals, and how does that interact with the requirement to notify members of prescribed particulars when a proposal has been received (including the timing relative to AGM and special meeting notices for Merger Resolutions)?
gold_answer: In applying to the PRA for approval of a Schedule 16 Statement, the application must be in writing and should include a declaration made on behalf of the board stating that the Statement is complete and contains all material information that, in the directors’ opinion, members should know. [#SRC:b23ef312764c9a50] That declaration should also explicitly state whether any other merger or takeover proposals exist (confidential or otherwise) and confirm that the information provided about those proposals is correct. [#SRC:b23ef312764c9a50] Where a proposal of either kind has been received, the society must also ensure members receive a notification containing the prescribed particulars, sent to every member entitled to notice of a meeting. [#TGT:e13932686034a534] This notification may be delivered as a standalone communication or bundled with each notice of the society’s annual general meeting. [#TGT:e13932686034a534] In addition, if the prescribed-particulars notification has not already been provided, it must be included with every notice of the special meeting at which Merger Resolutions are to be moved. [#TGT:e13932686034a534] Practically, the board’s declaration about other proposals supports completeness and accuracy in the PRA submission, while the member-notification duty governs how and when prescribed particulars about received proposals must be communicated around AGM and special-meeting notices. [#SRC:b23ef312764c9a50] [#TGT:e13932686034a534]
source_text: Schedule 16 Statements must be prepared to the same standards as apply to financial statements and directors reports. An application to the PRA for approval of a Schedule 16 Statement must be made in writing and should include a declaration made on behalf of the board, that the Statement is complete and includes all material information of which, in the opinion of the directors, the members should be aware. That declaration should say whether or not there have been any other merger or takeover proposals (confidential or otherwise see paragraph 3.89 – 3.90 ) and confirm that the information about them is correct.
